revision.text:
{{Dynamic list}} {{Infobox | headerstyle = background-color:#ddd; | header1 = Years in stand-up comedy | data2 = {{Space separated entries | [[2014 in stand-up comedy|2014]] | [[2015 in stand-up comedy|2015]] | [[2016 in stand-up comedy|2016]] | '''2017''' | [[2018 in stand-up comedy|2018]] | [[2019 in stand-up comedy|2019]] }} }}
This is a timeline documenting events and facts about [[stand-up comedy]] in the year 2017.
== Events ==
* February 14: ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' publishes a ranked [[listicle]] entitled ''50 Best Stand-Up Comics of All Time''. [[Richard Pryor]] ranks first, considering artistic merit, technical proficiency, [[Comic timing|sense of timing]], quality of written material, delivery and degree of influence.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/lists/50-best-stand-up-comics-of-all-time-w464199 |title=50 Best Stand-Up Comics of All Time |website=Rolling Stone |first=Matthew |last=Love |date=February 14, 2017 |accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref> * February 28: [[John Caparulo]] is assaulted by two women from the audience at [[The Comedy & Magic Club]] in Hermosa Beach, California, after making a phallic joke about [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rawstory.com/2017/03/trump-supporter-assaults-comedian-john-caparulo/ |title=VIDEO: Trump supporter assaults comedian John Caparulo in California club |website=Raw Story |first=Samantha |last=Karas |date=March 1, 2017 |accessdate=March 3, 2017}}</ref>
== Deaths ==
* April 6: [[Don Rickles]] dies of [[kidney failure]], at the age of 90, at his home in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/don-rickles-lightning-fast-launcher-of-comic-insults-dies-at-90/2017/04/06/d785d626-1af2-11e7-855e-4824bbb5d748_story.html |title=Don Rickles, lightning-fast launcher of comic insults, dies at 90 |website=The Washington Post |first=Matt |last=Schudel |date=April 6, 2017 |accessdate=April 7, 2017}}</ref> * April 12: [[Charlie Murphy]] dies at the age of 57 in New York, suffering from [[leukemia]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/04/12/entertainment/charlie-murphy-dead/index.html |title=Charlie Murphy has died after a battle with leukemia |website=CNN |first=Chloe |last=Melas |date=April 13, 2017 |accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref> * August 19: [[Dick Gregory]] dies of [[heart failure]] at the age of 84 in Washington.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-dick-gregory-20170819-story.html |title=Dick Gregory, who rose from poverty to become a groundbreaking comedian and civil rights activist, dies at 84 |last=McLellan |first=Dennis |date=August 19, 2017 |website=Los Angeles Times |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> * August 20: [[Jerry Lewis]] dies of [[cardiovascular disease]], at the age of 91, at his home in Las Vegas.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://variety.com/2017/film/people-news/jerry-lewis-dies-dead-nutty-professor-1202533899/ |title=Jerry Lewis, Comedy Legend, Dies at 91 |last1=Natale |first1=Richard |last2=Dagan |first2=Carmel |date=August 20, 2017 |website=Variety |access-date=December 25, 2017}}</ref> * September 19: [[Jake LaMotta]] dies of [[pneumonia]] at the age of 95 in Florida.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/20/sports/jake-lamotta-dead.html |title=Jake LaMotta, 'Raging Bull in and Out of the Ring, Dies at 95 |last=Goldstein |first=Richard |date=September 20, 2017 |website=The New York Times |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> * October 6: [[Ralphie May]] dies of [[cardiac arrest]] at the age of 45 in Las Vegas.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://splitsider.com/2017/10/ralphie-may-dies-at-45/ |title=Ralphie May Dies at 45 |last=Wright |first=Megh |date=October 6, 2017 |website=Splitsider |access-date=October 8, 2017}}</ref> * October 16: [[Sean Hughes (comedian)|Sean Hughes]] dies of cardiac arrest at the age of 51, while also suffering from [[cirrhosis]] of the liver.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/global/2017/oct/19/remembering-sean-hughes-the-sadness-is-he-didnt-get-to-be-old-just-lonely |title=Remembering Sean Hughes: ‘The sadness is he didn’t get to be old, just lonely’ |last=Hann |first=Michael |date=October 19, 2017 |website=The Guardian |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref>
== Releases == {{Missing information|section|[[Comedy album|albums]], DVDs and half-hour [[Television special|specials]]|date=December 2017}} {{Refimprove section|date=December 2017}}
=== January ===
* January 3: [[Jen Kirkman]]'s one-hour special ''Just Keep Livin’?'' is released on [[Netflix]]. The special was filmed at the [[Bowery Ballroom]] in New York.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/12/jen-kirkman-just-keep-livin-trailer-netflix-special-1201763297/ |title=‘Just Keep Livin’?’ Trailer: Comedian Jen Kirkman Returns For a Second Netflix Special |last=Murthi |first=Vikram |date=December 28, 2016 |website=IndieWire |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> * January 5: [[Brian Posehn]]'s one-hour special ''Posehn 25x2'' is released on [[Seeso]].<ref name="Posehn">{{Cite web |url=http://brianposehn.com/site/2017/03/10/185-2/ |title=The new album from Brian Posehn POSEHN 25X2 Available Now! |author=Staff |date=March 10, 2017 |website=Brian Posehn |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Revolution Hall]] in Portland, Oregon.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theblacklistnyc.com/brianp |title=Posehn 25x2 |author=Staff |website=The Black List NYC |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> * January 6th: [[Janeane Garofalo]] album version of her October 26 special ''If I May'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. The album was recorded in San Francisco, California. * January 10: [[Jim Gaffigan]]'s one-hour special ''Cinco'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="GaffiganBrennanAlonzoElmalehNetflix">{{Cite web |url=http://fox2now.com/2016/12/16/everything-coming-and-going-on-netflix-in-january/ |title=Everything coming and going on Netflix in January |author=Tribune Media |date=December 16, 2016 |website=FOX2now.com |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Palace Theatre (Columbus, Ohio)|Palace Theatre]] in Columbus, Ohio.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * January 13: [[Kelly MacFarland]]'s album ''You Woke Up Today'' is released on [[iTunes]] and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] by Rooftop Comedy. The album was recorded at the [[ImprovBoston]] in Cambridge, Massachusetts.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://theinterrobang.com/kelly-macfarland-holds-pajama-party-themed-album-release-event/ |title=Kelly MacFarland Holds Pajama Party Themed Album Release Event |website=The Interrobang |first=Amma |last=Marfo |date=January 19, 2017 |accessdate=July 3, 2017}}</ref> * January 13: Mo Mandel's album version of his November 2016 special ''Negative Reinforcement'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. The album was recorded at the [[Gothic Theatre|Gothic Theater]] in Denver, Colorado. * January 17: [[Neal Brennan]]'s one-hour special ''3 Mics'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="GaffiganBrennanAlonzoElmalehNetflix" /> The special was filmed at the Belasco Theatre in Los Angeles.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * January 20: [[Dan Levy]]'s album version of his November 2016 special ''Lion'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * January 20: [[Jena Friedman]]'s album version of her October 2016 special ''American Cunt'' is released on [[iTunes]]. The album was recorded at [[The Slipper Room]] in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thelaughbutton.com/albums/album-version-jena-friedmans-american-cnt-will-available-january/ |title=The album version of Jena Friedman’s ''American C*nt'' will be available this January |website=The Laugh Button |author=Mark Says Hi! |date=December 21, 2016 |accessdate=July 3, 2017}}</ref> * January 24: [[Cristela Alonzo]]'s one-hour special ''Lower Classy'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="GaffiganBrennanAlonzoElmalehNetflix" /> The special was filmed at the Empire Theatre in San Antonio.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * January 24: [[Gad Elmaleh]]'s one-hour special ''Gad Gone Wild'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="GaffiganBrennanAlonzoElmalehNetflix" /> The special was filmed at the L'Olympia in Montreal{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} and performed mainly in French.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://thelaughbutton.com/video/heres-first-look-gad-elmalehs-special-gad-gone-wild-coming-netflix/ |title=Here's your first look at Gad Elmaleh's special "Gad Gone Wild" coming to Netflix |author=Mark Says Hi! |date=January 11, 2017 |website=The Laugh Button |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> * January 26: [[Adam Newman (comedian)|Adam Newman]]'s one-hour special ''Fuzzies'' is released on Seeso.<ref name="Newman">{{Cite web |url=http://splitsider.com/2016/11/seeso-announces-2017-premiere-dates-for-new-and-returning-shows-and-standup-specials/ |title=Seeso Announces 2017 Premiere Dates for New and Returning Shows and Standup Specials |last=Wright |first=Megh |date=November 1, 2016 |website=Splitsider |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Georgia Theatre]] in Athens, Georgia.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * January 27: [[Aries Spears]]' album version of his November 2016 special ''Comedy Blueprint'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. The special was filmed in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. * January 31: [[Bill Burr]]'s one-hour special ''Walk Your Way Out'' is released on Netflix.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/01/bill-burr-returns-with-new-stand-up-special-walk-y.html |title=Bill Burr to Return with New Netflix Stand-Up Special Walk Your Way Out |last=McNett |first=Jared |date=January 18, 2017 |website=Paste |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] in Nashville, Tennessee.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}}
=== February ===
* February 3: [[Joe DeRosa (comedian)|Joe DeRosa]]'s one-hour special ''You Let Me Down'' is released on [[Comedy Central]]. The special was filmed at The Masonic Lodge at [[Hollywood Forever Cemetery]] in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://press.cc.com/press-release/2017/01/27/press-joe-derosa-you-let-me-down-premieres-february-3-at-midnight-etpt |title=PRESS – Joe DeRosa You Let Me Down Premieres February 3 at Midnight ETPT |website=Comedy Central}}</ref> * February 3: [[Katie Goodman]]'s album ''Halfway Closer to Dead'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * February 10: [[Nick Cannon]]'s one-hour special ''Stand Up Don't Shoot!'' is released on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]. The special was filmed at the Ebony Repertory Theatre in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sho.com/titles/3438320/nick-cannon-stand-up-dont-shoot |title=Nick Cannon: Stand Up, Don't Shoot |website=Showtime}}</ref> * February 10: [[Joey Diaz|Joey Coco Diaz]]'s album version of his December 2016 special ''Sociably Unacceptable'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * February 14: [[Katherine Ryan]]'s one-hour special ''In Trouble'' is released on [[Netflix]]. The special was filmed at the [[Hammersmith Apollo]] in London.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2017/01/18/26657/netflix_signs_katherine_ryan |title=Netflix signs Katherine Ryan, Stand-up special out on Valentine's Day |website=Chortle}}</ref> * February 16: [[Nick Di Paolo]]'s one-hour special ''Inflammatory'' is released on [[Seeso]].<ref>{{Cite tweet |number=830607505243926528 |user=NickDiPaolo |title=My all new special “INFLAMMATORY” premieres on @SeesoTV 2/16! |author=Nick Di Paolo |date=February 12, 2017 |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the Suffolk Theater in Riverhead, New York.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * February 17: [[Andy Kindler]]'s album ''State of the Industry'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * February 16: [[Gina Yashere]]'s one-hour special ''Ticking Boxes'' is released on Seeso. The special was filmed at the [[O2 Brixton Academy]] in London.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://ginayashere.com/ |title=Gina Yashere |website=Gina Yashere |accessdate=February 20, 2017}}</ref> * February 19: [[Roy Wood Jr.]]'s one-hour special ''Father Figure'' is released on Comedy Central. The special was filmed at the [[Center Stage Atlanta|Center Stage Theater]] in Atlanta.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/Roy-Wood-Jrs-Stand-Up-Special-FATHER-FIGURE-to-Debut-on-Comedy-Central-219-20170207 |title=Roy Wood Jr's Stand Up Special FATHER FIGURE to Debut on Comedy Central 2/19 |last=Desk |first=TV News |accessdate=February 9, 2017 |website=BroadwayWorld}}</ref> * February 21: [[Trevor Noah]]'s one-hour special ''Afraid of the Dark'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Beacon Theatre (New York City)|Beacon Theatre]] in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/trevor-noah-comedy-special-afraid-dark-set-netflix-968156? |title=Trevor Noah Comedy Special 'Afraid of the Dark' Set for Netflix |website=Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> * February 24: [[Nick Thune]]'s album version of his December 2016 special ''Good Guy'' is released on [[iTunes]]. The album was recorded in Portland, Oregon. * February 28: [[Mike Birbiglia]]'s one-hour special ''Thank God for Jokes'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Brooklyn Academy of Music|BAM Harvey Theater]] in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ew.com/tv/2017/01/24/mike-birbiglia-thank-god-jokes-netflix/ |title=Mike Birbiglia's Thank God for Jokes is heading to Netflix |website=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref>
=== March ===
* March 3: [[Kurt Braunohler]]'s one-hour special ''Trust Me'' is released on [[Comedy Central]]. The special was filmed at the [[Revolution Hall]] in Portland, Oregon.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://press.cc.com/press-release/2017/02/14/press-kurt-braunohler-trust-me-debuts-limited-commercial-interruption-friday-march-3-at-midnight |title=PRESS – Kurt Braunohler Trust Me Debuts Limited Commercial Interruption Friday March 3 at Midnight |website=Comedy Central Press |accessdate=February 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ticketfly.com/event/1286547-kurt-braunohler-portland/ |title=Kurt Braunohler – Tickets – Revolution Hall – Portland, OR – September 24, 2016 |website=Ticketfly |accessdate=February 22, 2017}}</ref> * March 3: [[Ian Harvie]]'s album version of his December 2016 special ''May the Best Cock Win'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * March 3: [[Diane Spencer]]'s one-hour special ''Seamless'' is released on [[YouTube]]. The special was filmed at The Ent Shed in Bedford.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FwmJIWxr7vY |title=Diane Spencer: Seamless (2017) |website=YouTube |accessdate=March 4, 2017}}</ref> * March 7: [[Amy Schumer]]'s one-hour special ''The Leather Special'' is released on [[Netflix]]. The special was filmed at the Bellco Theatre in Denver.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://media.netflix.com/en/press-releases/amy-schumer-comes-to-netflix-with-all-net-original-stand-up-comedy-special |title=Amy Schumer Comes to Netflix with All-Net Original Stand-Up Comedy Special |website=Netflix}}</ref><ref name="SchumerNortonNetoKoy-NetflixMarch">{{cite web |url=http://thelaughbutton.com/news/netflixs-march-comedy-specials-include-amy-schumer-jim-norton-felipe-neto-jo-koy/ |title=Netflix's March comedy specials to include Amy Schumer, Jim Norton, Felipe Neto, and Jo Koy |website=The Laugh Button |accessdate=February 27, 2017}}</ref> * March 9: [[Fahim Anwar]]'s one-hour special ''There's No Business Like Show Business'' is released on [[Seeso]].<ref name="Anwar">{{Cite web |url=http://www.comedydynamics.com/fahim-anwar-theres-no-business-like-show-business/ |title=Fahim Anwar: There's No Business Like Show Business |author=Staff |website=Comedy Dynamics |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Alex Theatre]] in Glendale, California.{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} * March 10: [[Brian Posehn]]'s album version of his January 2017 special ''Posehn 25x2'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] and [[Google Play]] by Comedy Dynamics.<ref name="Posehn" /> * March 11: [[Jerrod Carmichael]]'s one-hour special ''8'' is released on [[HBO]]. The special was filmed at the [[Masonic Hall (Manhattan)|Masonic Hall]] in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thelaughbutton.com/jerrod-carmichael/jerrod-carmichaels-new-special-8-premires-march-11th-hbo/ |title=Jerrod Carmichael’s new special, "8" premieres on HBO March 11th |website=The Laugh Button |accessdate=February 22, 2017}}</ref> * March 14: [[Jim Norton (comedian)|Jim Norton]]'s one-hour special ''Mouthful of Shame'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Skirball Center for the Performing Arts|Skirball Center]] in New York.<ref name="SchumerNortonNetoKoy-NetflixMarch"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theblacklistnyc.com/jimnorton |title=Jim Norton: Mouthful of Shame |website=The Black List NYC}}</ref> * March 17: Mike Finola's album ''Live in Burlington'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * March 18: [[K. Trevor Wilson]]'s half-hour special ''Bigger in Person'' is released on [[The Comedy Network]]. The special was filmed at the L’Astral in Montreal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thelaughbutton.com/k-trevor-wilson/check-trailer-k-trevor-wilsons-upcoming-special-bigger-person/ |title=Check out the trailer for K. Trevor Wilson's upcoming special, "Bigger in Person" |website=The Laugh Button |first=Samantha |last=Pitchell |date=March 15, 2017 |accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://theinterrobang.com/preparing-roast-battle/ |title=How Do You Prepare for The Biggest Roast Battle Yet? K. Trevor Wilson Shares His Plan for Just For Laughs |website=The Interrobang |first=Barry |last=Taylor |date=July 26, 2016 |accessdate=June 30, 2017}}</ref> * March 21: [[Dave Chappelle]]'s one-hour special ''Deep in the Heart of Texas'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Moody Theater]] in Austin, Texas.<ref name="ChappelleNetflix-DoubleRelease">{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/tv/ct-dave-chappelle-netflix-comedy-specials-20170302-story.html |title=Dave Chappelle debuts 2 comedy specials March 21 on Netflix |website=ChicagoTribune |accessdate=March 3, 2017 |language=en-US}}</ref> * March 21: Dave Chappelle's one-hour special ''The Age of Spin'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Hollywood Palladium]] in Los Angeles.<ref name="ChappelleNetflix-DoubleRelease"/> * March 24: [[Wil Anderson]]'s one-hour special ''Fire at Wil'' is released on [[Stan (company)|Stan]]. The special was filmed at the [[Comedy Theatre, Melbourne|Comedy Theatre]] in Melbourne.<ref name="StanAustralia6specials-tvTonight">{{cite web |url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2017/03/one-night-stan-wil-anderson-celia-pacquola.html |title=One Night Stan: Wil Anderson, Celia Pacquola |website=TV Tonight |accessdate=April 8, 2017}}</ref><ref name="StanAustralia6specials-Lifehacker">{{cite web |url=https://www.lifehacker.com.au/2017/03/everything-coming-to-netflix-stan-amazon-and-foxtel-this-april/ |title=Everything Coming To Netflix, Stan And Foxtel This April |website=Lifehacker Australia |accessdate=April 8, 2017}}</ref> * March 27: [[Tom Walker (comedian)|Tom Walker]]'s one-hour special ''[[Jonathan Pie]]: LIVE!'' is released on JonathanPie.com. The special was filmed at the [[Shepherd's Bush Empire]] in London.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/people/tom_walker/shop/5356/jonathan_pie_live/ |title=Jonathan Pie: LIVE! Download |website=British Comedy Guide |accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> * March 28: [[Jo Koy]]'s one-hour special ''Live from Seattle'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Moore Theatre]] in Seattle.<ref name="SchumerNortonNetoKoy-NetflixMarch"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.axs.com/news/interview-jo-koy-to-film-his-next-comedy-special-at-the-moore-theatre-81253 |title=Interview: Jo Koy to film his next comedy special at The Moore Theatre |website=AXS}}</ref> * March 29: [[Adam Rowe]]'s one-hour special ''I Know What You're Saying'' is released on [[Gumroad]]. The special was filmed at the Hot Water Comedy Club in Liverpool.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gumroad.com/l/JbjP# |title=Adam Rowe: I Know What You're Saying |website=Gumroad |accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> * March 30: [[Sasheer Zamata]]'s one-hour special ''Pizza Mind'' is released on Seeso.<ref name="Zamata">{{Cite web |url=http://www.comedydynamics.com/sasheer-zamata-pizza-mind-audio/ |title=Sasheer Zamata: Pizza Mind (Audio) |author=Staff |website=Comedy Dynamics |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Civic Theatre (New Orleans)|Civic Theatre]] in New Orleans.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cduniverse.com/productinfo.asp?pid=10922374&style=music&msg=2 |title=Sasheer Zamata - Pizza Mind CD Album |website=CD Universe |access-date=December 15, 2017}}</ref> * March 31: [[Celia Pacquola]]'s one-hour special ''The Looking Glass'' is released on Stan. The special was filmed at the Comedy Theatre in Melbourne.<ref name="StanAustralia6specials-tvTonight"/><ref name="StanAustralia6specials-Lifehacker"/> * March 31: Adam Newman's album version of his January 2017 special ''Fuzzies'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. The album was recorded at the [[Georgia Theatre]] in Athens, GA.
=== April ===
* April 4: [[Louis C.K.]]'s one-hour special ''Louis C.K. 2017'' is released on [[Netflix]]. The special was filmed at the [[DAR Constitution Hall]] in Washington.<ref name="UpcomingNetflixSpecials-LouisCK-Seinfeld-Chappelle-Rock">{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/louis-ck-netflix-new-specials-stand-up-1201993716/ |title=Louis C.K. Inks Deal With Netflix for Two Stand-Up Specials |last=Schwindt |first=Oriana |date=February 22, 2017 |website=Variety |accessdate=February 22, 2017 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://wtop.com/entertainment/2017/02/underground-comedy-surprises-dc-with-louis-ck-patton-oswalt/ |title=Underground Comedy surprises DC with Louis CK, Patton Oswalt |accessdate=February 22, 2017 |website=WTOP}}</ref> * April 7: [[Tom Ballard]]'s one-hour special ''The World Keeps Happening'' is released on [[Stan (company)|Stan]]. The special was filmed at the [[Comedy Theatre, Melbourne|Comedy Theatre]] in Melbourne.<ref name="StanAustralia6specials-tvTonight"/><ref name="StanAustralia6specials-Lifehacker"/> * April 7: [[Steve Byrne]]'s one-hour special ''Tell the Damn Joke'' is released on [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]]. The special was filmed at the [[Lincoln Hall (Chicago)|Lincoln Hall]] in Chicago.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thelaughbutton.com/specials/steve-byrne-to-tape-his-4th-special-in-chicago-early-2016/ |title=Steve Byrne to tape his 4th special in Chicago early 2016 |website=The Laugh Button}}</ref><ref name="UpcomingShowtimeSpecials-Madrigal-Santino-Griffin-Byrne"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/stevebyrnelive/status/835963978077462528 |title=Steve Byrne - Tell the Damn Joke |website=Twitter |accessdate=February 27, 2017}}</ref> * April 14: [[Sam Simmons (comedian)|Sam Simmons]]'s one-hour special ''Stop Being Silly'' is released on Stan. The special was filmed at the Comedy Theatre in Melbourne.<ref name="StanAustralia6specials-tvTonight"/><ref name="StanAustralia6specials-Lifehacker"/> * April 14: [[Bill Hicks]]' album version of his 1992 special ''Relentless'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * April 18: [[Kenny and Keith Lucas|The Lucas Brothers]]' one-hour special ''On Drugs'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at [[The Bell House (New York City)|The Bell House]] in New York.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thelaughbutton.com/news/netflix-announces-new-releases-april-including-specials-lucas-brothers-louis-c-k/ |title=Netflix announces its comedy releases in April, including specials from The Lucas Brothers, Louis C.K. |website=The Laugh Button |accessdate=April 5, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/comedydynamics/status/794664658690928641 |title=Comedy Dynamics - Lucas Brothers |website=Twitter |accessdate=April 5, 2017}}</ref> * April 18: [[Dan Cummins]]'s one-hour special ''Don’t Wake the Bear'' is released on [[Google Play]], [[iTunes]], [[Steam (software)|Steam]] and [[Vudu]]. The special was filmed at [[The Depot]] in Salt Lake.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comedydynamics.com/dan-cummins-dont-wake-the-bear/ |title=Comedy Dynamics to release Dan Cummins’ latest special 'Don’t Wake the Bear' on April 18, 2017 |website=Comedy Dynamics |accessdate=April 27, 2017}}</ref> * April 20: [[Brent Weinbach]]'s one-hour special ''Appealing to the Mainstream'' is released on [[Seeso]]. The special was filmed at the Colony Theatre in Burbank, California.<ref name="WeinbachNormand-Vulture">{{cite web |url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/03/spring-comedy-preview-dave-chappelle-louis-c-k-sarah-silverman.html |title=Spring Comedy Preview: Dave Chappelle, Louis C.K., and More |website=Vulture |accessdate=April 8, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://on-camera-audiences.com/shows/Brent_Weinbach_Live_Taping |title=Brent Weinbach Live Taping |website=On Camera Audiences}}</ref> * April 21: [[Nick Di Paolo|Nick DiPaolo]]'s album version of his February 2018 special ''Inflammatory'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * April 21: [[Judith Lucy]]'s one-hour special ''Ask No Questions of the Moth'' is released on Stan. The special was filmed at the Comedy Theatre in Melbourne.<ref name="StanAustralia6specials-tvTonight"/><ref name="StanAustralia6specials-Lifehacker"/> * April 25: [[Vir Das]]'s one-hour special ''Abroad Understanding'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Skirball Center for the Performing Arts|Skirball Center]] in New York.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.eponymousreview.com/3054/michelle-wolf-comedy-special-nice-lady-premiere-hbo-december/ |title=Michelle Wolf's debut comedy special 'Nice Lady' hits HBO in December |author=Staff |date=November 1, 2017 |website=Eponymous Review |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> * December 5: [[Craig Ferguson]]'s one-hour special ''Tickle Fight'' is released on [[Netflix]]. The special was filmed at the Ludger-Duvernay Theatre in Montreal.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/11/watch-the-trailer-for-craig-fergusons-new-standup.html |title=Watch the Trailer for Craig Ferguson's Netflix Standup Special, Tickle Fight |last=McAdams |first=Eric |date=November 27, 2017 |website=Paste |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> * December 8: [[Lavell Crawford]]'s album version of his special ''Home for the Holidays'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * December 12: [[Judd Apatow]]'s one-hour special ''The Return'' is released on Netflix. The special was filmed at the [[Place des Arts|Cinquieme Salle]] in Montreal.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/montreal/article/Kevin-Hart-Jim-Carey-Ali-Wong-Trevor-Noah-Headline-JUST-FOR-LAUGHS-20170731 |title=Kevin Hart, Jim Carey, Ali Wong, Trevor Noah Headline JUST FOR LAUGHS |author=BWW News Desk |date=July 31, 2017 |website=BroadwayWorld |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2017/12/08/judd-apatow-netflix-special-sex-harassment/933286001/ |title=Judd Apatow feared his Netflix's special's Cosby jokes might go stale. He was wrong. |last=Keveney |first=Bill |date=December 8, 2017 |website=USA TODAY |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> * December 15: Nick Hoff's album ''Baby Daddy'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * December 15: Ian Harris's album version of his special ''ExtraOrdinary'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * December 19: [[Russell Howard]]'s one-hour special ''Recalibrate'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="NetflixDecember">{{Cite web |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/netflix-originals-shows-and-movies-coming-out-in-december-list-2017-11 |title=All 14 new Netflix original TV shows and movies coming out in December |last=Wittmer |first=Carrie |date=December 1, 2017 |website=Business Insider |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> The special was filmed at the [[Brighton Dome]] in Brighton.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2017/08/04/37312/russell_howard_shoots_netflix_special |title=Russell Howard shoots Netflix special |last=Richardson |first=Jay |date=August 4, 2017 |website=Chortle |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> * December 22: [[Bill Hicks]]'s album version of his 1993 special ''Revelations'' is released on [[iTunes]], [[Google Play]], [[Spotify]] and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * December 26: [[Todd Barry]]'s one-hour special ''Spicy Honey'' is released on Netflix.<ref name="NetflixDecember" /> The special was filmed at the [[Music Hall of Williamsburg]] in New York.<ref>{{Cite tweet |number=856894757464932352 |user=toddbarry |title=I'm taping a one-hour special in #Brooklyn -- @MusicHallofWB -- May 4th. |author=Todd Barry |date=April 25, 2017 |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref> * December 26: [[Taylor Williamson]]'s one-hour special ''Please Like Me'' is released on Comedy Dynamics Network. The special was filmed in Denver, CO. * December 26: [[Taylor Williamson]]'s album version of his special ''Please Like Me'' is released on iTunes, Google Play, Spotify and other digital audio retailers by Comedy Dynamics. * December 31: [[Dave Chappelle]]'s two one-hour specials ''Equanimity'' and ''The Bird Revelation'' were released on Netflix. The specials were filmed at the [[Warner Theatre (Washington, D.C.)|Warner Theatre]] in Washington and Los Angeles respectively.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dailynews.com/2017/11/27/netflix-is-adding-a-bunch-of-new-movies-and-tv-shows-this-december/ |title=Netflix is adding a bunch of new movies and TV shows this December |last=Lowman |first=Rob |date=November 27, 2017 |website=Daily News |access-date=December 13, 2017}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of stand-up comedians]]

revision.text:
[[File:2020 Casting HopgoodSt.jpg|thumb|2020 Casting, Shepherd's Bush]] '''2020 Casting''' (now Mad Dog 2020 Casting) is a casting agency based in [[London]], England which supplies extras for film shoots. Previously, it was located in [[Hopgood St]], [[Shepherd's Bush]], in West London. 2020 casting merged with Mad Dog Casting in 2017 to form Mad Dog 2020 Casting and is now based in Ealing Studios.
The agency was founded by actor [[Christopher Villiers]] and personal trainer Richard Smedley who met on the set of the film [[First Knight]] in around 1995. 2020 was "the first agency to take digital photographs of its artistes", and "the first to use text messaging systems to contact our artistes".<ref>[http://www.2020casting.com/pages/background.php Background - Official 2020 website] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121230110903/http://www.2020casting.com/pages/background.php |date=2012-12-30 }} Retrieved December 2012</ref>
Villiers is known for his part in the top rated [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] [[soap opera]], ''[[Emmerdale]]'' in which he played the role of the [[solicitor]] [[Grayson Sinclair]].
2020 Casting has a sister agency, SA19<ref>http://www.SA19.co.uk</ref> that is a leading supplier of uniformed supporting artistes to the UK film and television industry.
2020 claims to have 2,600 artistes registered on their books, with a backup database of well over 30,000.<ref>[http://www.2020casting.com/pages/wedo.php What We Do - Official 2020 website] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130101094300/http://www.2020casting.com/pages/wedo.php |date=2013-01-01 }} Retrieved December 2012</ref> They have supplied extras for more than 200 films, including [[Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire]], [[Shaun of the Dead]] and [[Bridget Jones's Diary]].<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/company/co0002463/ Internet Movie Database] Retrieved December 2012</ref>
==References== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=YshOYecAD0oC&pg=PA8&dq=20/20+casting+agency&hl=en&sa=X&ei=RLvRULSSM4ua1AXhyICwAg&ved=0CD0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=20%2F20%20casting%20agency&f=false Jones, Chris ''Guerilla Film Makers Movie Blueprint''] Continuum International Publishing Group (2003) {{ISBN|978-0826414533}} Retrieved December 2012
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120729172246/http://www.2020casting.com/pages/contact.php 2020 Official website] Retrieved December 2012 *[http://www.theactingwebsite.com/20-20-castings-i3648.html 2020 at www.theactingwebsite.com] Retrieved December 2012
[[Category:Talent and literary agencies]]

Robot - Moving category Stock characters in Ancient Greek comedy to [[:Category:Stock characters in ancient Greek comedy]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 September 1]].
revision.text:
{{about||the river|Alazani}} {{redirect|Miles Gloriosus|the Plautus play|Miles Gloriosus (play)}} '''''Alazṓn''''' ({{lang-grc|ἀλαζών}}) is one of three [[stock characters]] in [[Ancient Greek comedy|comedy]] of the [[theatre of ancient Greece]].<ref>Carlson (1993, 23) and Janko (1987, 45, 170).</ref> He is the opponent of the ''[[Eiron|eirôn]]''. The ''alazṓn'' is an [[impostor]] that sees himself as greater than he actually is. The '''''senex iratus''''' (the angry father) and the '''''miles gloriosus''''' (the glorious soldier) are two types of ''alazṓn''.<ref name=Frye>Frye, Northrop. 1957. ''Anatomy of Criticism: Four Essays''. London: Penguin, 1990. {{ISBN|0-14-012480-2}}.</ref>
==''Miles Gloriosus''== {{wiktionary|miles gloriosus}} ''Miles Gloriosus'' (literally, "braggart-soldier", in [[Latin language|Latin]]) is a [[stock character]] of a boastful soldier from the [[Comedy (drama)|comic]] [[theatre of ancient Rome]], and variations on this character have appeared in [[drama]] and [[fiction]] ever since.<ref name=Frye /> The character derives from the ''alazṓn'' or "braggart" of the [[Ancient Greek comedy#Old Comedy|Greek Old Comedy]] (e.g. [[Aristophanes]]). The term "Miles Gloriosus" is occasionally applied in a contemporary context to refer to a posturing and self-deceiving boaster or bully.
=== Literary instances === In the play ''[[Miles Gloriosus (play)|Miles Gloriosus]]'' by [[Plautus]], the term applies to the main character Pyrgopolynices. This foolish ''Miles Gloriosus'' brags openly and often about his supposed greatness, while the rest of the characters feign their admiration and secretly plot against him. Heavily borrowing from Plautus, the [[Stephen Sondheim]]-[[Burt Shevelove]]-[[Larry Gelbart]] musical ''[[A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum]]'' features a warrior named Miles Gloriosus.
Shakespeare uses the type most notably with the bombastic and self-glorifying ensign [[Ancient Pistol]] in ''[[Henry IV, Part 2]]'', ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]'' and ''[[Henry V (play)|Henry V]]''.<ref>Victor L. Cahn, Shakespeare the Playwright: A Companion to the Complete Tragedies, Histories, Comedies, and Romances, Praeger, Westport, 1996. p.468.</ref> Other examples are "fashion's own knight", the Spaniard Armardo, in ''[[Love's Labour's Lost]]'', the worthless Captain Parolles in ''[[All's Well That Ends Well]]'', and [[Falstaff]] in ''[[Henry IV, Part 1]]'' and ''[[Henry IV, Part 2|Part 2]]'', and ''[[The Merry Wives of Windsor]]''.
[[Baron Munchausen]] is a braggart soldier.
In [[Commedia dell'arte]], the figure of [[Il Capitano]] is a ''miles gloriosus''.<ref>John Rudlin, ''Commedia dell'Arte: An Actor's Handbook'', p. 120, {{ISBN|0-415-04770-6}}.</ref>
In music, the title role of ''[[Háry János]]'' by [[Kodály]] is an example of the character.
In PC game ''[[The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind]]'', there is a non-playable character named Miles Gloriosus, willing to brag about his accomplishments as soldier.
==''Senex iratus''== The ''senex iratus'' or heavy father figure is a comic [[archetype]] character who belongs to the alazon or impostor group in [[theater]], manifesting himself through his rages and threats, his obsessions and his gullibility.
His usual function is to impede the love of the [[lovers (character)|hero and heroine]], and his power to do so stems from his greater social position and his increased control of cash. In the [[New Comedy]], he was often the father of the hero and so his rival. More frequently since, he has been the father of the heroine who insists on her union with the bad fiancé; as such, he appears in both ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]'', where he fails and so the play is a comedy, and ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'', where his acts are successful enough to render the play a tragedy.
[[Pantalone]] in [[Commedia dell'arte]] acts as a ''senex iratus''.
In his ''[[Anatomy of Criticism]]'', [[Northrop Frye]] considered all blocking humors in comedy to be variations on the basic function of the ''senex iratus''.
==See also== * [[Boasting]] * ''[[Bomolochus|Bômolochus]]'' * ''[[Eiron|Eirôn]]'' * [[Exaggeration]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Carlson, Marvin. 1993. ''Theories of the Theatre: A Historical and Critical Survey from the Greeks to the Present.'' Expanded. Ithaca and London: Cornell University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-8014-8154-3}}. * Janko, Richard, trans. 1987. ''Poetics with Tractatus Coislinianus, Reconstruction of Poetics II and the Fragments of the On Poets.'' By [[Aristotle]]. Cambridge: Hackett. {{ISBN|0-87220-033-7}}.
==External links== *[http://virtual.clemson.edu/groups/dial/sfclass/Fryechar.htm Character Functions]
{{Stock characters}} {{All's Well That Ends Well}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Ancient Greek theatre]] [[Category:Stock characters in ancient Greek comedy]] [[Category:Antagonists by role]] [[Category:Fictional impostors]]

{{multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=March 2013}} {{cleanup|date=May 2011}} {{primary sources|date=March 2015}} }} The '''Alberta Foundation for the Arts''' (AFA), based in [[Edmonton]], is a [[Crown Agency|crown agency]] of the [[Government of Alberta]]. As the primary [[arts funding]] body in [[Alberta]], it plays a key role in supporting the Spirit of Alberta,[http://www.culture.alberta.ca/about/premiers-council/pdf/SpiritofAlberta.pdf Spirit of Alberta Policy] Alberta's Cultural Policy. The AFA exists to fund, encourage, and support the development of the [[art]]s as a valuable contributor to quality of life in Alberta and, to develop the AFA art collection as a cultural resource for all Albertans. == Background == The AFA was founded in 1991.[http://www.qp.alberta.ca/documents/Acts/A19.pdf Alberta Foundation for the Arts Act] Its mandate is to support and contribute to the development of the arts in Alberta. It brought under its mandate: the Alberta Art Foundation, the Alberta Foundation for the Performing Arts, the Alberta Foundation for the Literary Arts, and the arts and cultural grant programs of Alberta Culture and Multiculturalism. The AFA is governed by a Board of Directors. The AFA reports annually to Alberta's Minister of Culture and Community Spirit and supports the Ministry's [[business plan]] through its arts policy.[http://www.culture.alberta.ca/about/premiers-council/pdf/SpiritofAlberta.pdf Spirit of Alberta Policy] The AFA receives an annual allocation from the Alberta Lottery Fund, which it distributes to [[artist]]s and art organizations across Alberta through a variety of programs. == Activities == ===Granting programs=== Grants are available by application.[http://www.affta.ab.ca/Grants Grant Program] All AFA project [[Grant (money)|grants]] are awarded by independent juries whose members are selected from the Canadian arts community. The granting programs are organized into the following three categories, with specific streams below: :I. Arts Organizations: Operational :*Community Support Organizations :*Provincial Arts Service Organizations :*Community Performing Arts Organizations :*Community Presenting :*Professional Performing Arts Organizations :*Public Galleries :*Arts Presenting :*[[Summer school|Summer School]] Operations :II. Arts Organizations: Projects :*Artists and [[Education]] :*Cultural Relations :*Organizations Art Projects :*Post Secondary Institutions :III. Individual Artists: Projects :*Aboriginal Traditional Arts :*Cultural Relations :*[[Dance]] :*Film and Video Arts :*Literary Arts :*[[Music]] :*Theatre and Performance Arts :*Visual Arts and New Media ===AFA art collection=== The AFA art collection,[https://hermis.alberta.ca/afa/ Alberta Art Collections] established in 1972, is the only collection of its kind dedicated to showcasing the development of Alberta's [[visual arts]] achievements. Art maintenance and conservation ensures that the handling, preparation and preservation of artwork are conducted according to museum and archival standards. The collection contains over 8,000 works of art and is valued at over $10 million. More than 1,700 Alberta artists, many of whom are historically important individuals in the growth of the visual arts in Alberta, are represented in this collection. The AFA also hosts a virtual art museum.[http://alberta.emuseum.com/ Virtual Art Collection] ===Travelling Exhibition Program=== Since the program's introduction during Alberta's 75th Anniversary Celebrations in 1980, the AFA has supported a provincial [[Travelling exhibition|Traveling Exhibition]] (TREX) program. The TREX program strives to ensure every Albertan is provided with an opportunity to enjoy a visual arts exhibition in their community. The TREX program allows exhibitions from the Alberta art collection to be hosted in communities throughout Alberta. Venues include public libraries, [[school]]s, post-secondary institutions, [[hospital]]s and [[health care]] facilities, community halls and tourism centers. The TREX program also offers educational support material for [[educator]]s to integrate visual arts into the school curriculum.
Four regional organizations now coordinate the program for the AFA: *The Prairie Art Gallery, [[Grande Prairie, Alberta|Grande Prairie]] - Northwest Alberta *[[Art Gallery of Alberta]], [[Edmonton]] - Northeast and North Central Alberta *Alberta Society of Artists, [[Calgary]] - Southwest Alberta *Esplanade Arts & Heritage Centre, [[Medicine Hat]] - Southeast Alberta ===Arts promotion and capacity building=== The AFA supports the arts through various promotional strategies such as [[Alberta Culture Days]] which activities help to generate awareness of the arts with both the public and key [[Stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholder]]s. This is overseen by the Premier's Council for the Arts [http://www.culture.alberta.ca/about/premiers-council/default.aspx Premier's Council] Also, the AFA strives to build capacity among Alberta artists and art organizations by providing expert consulting support and grant application advice. These resources are used to build stronger, more sustainable arts organizations. == External links == * [http://www.affta.ab.ca/default.aspx Alberta Foundation for the Arts] * [https://hermis.alberta.ca/afa Alberta Foundation for the Arts Art Collection] * [http://www.affta.ab.ca/grants.aspx Alberta Foundation for the Arts Grant programming] * [http://www.facebook.com/home.php?#!/pages/Alberta-Foundation-for-the-Arts/126021084081360?ref=sgm AFA at Facebook] * [http://www.culture.alberta.ca/culturalpolicy/default.aspx The Spirit of Alberta – Alberta’s Cultural Policy] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100209045212/http://www.affta.ab.ca/travelling-exhibition.aspx TREX Program: Monthly Venue Map] ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Alberta Foundation For The Arts}} [[Category:Organizations based in Edmonton]] [[Category:Crown corporations of Alberta]] [[Category:Arts councils of Canada]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1991]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Alberta]]

revision.text:
[[File:VandA Rotunda.jpg|thumb|[[Dale Chihuly]]'s [[V&A Rotunda Chandelier|30-foot blown-glass chandelier]] in the [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] in 2000]] '''American craft''' is craft work produced by independent studio artists, working with traditional [[craft]] materials and/or processes such as [[wood]], [[woodworking]] or [[furniture|furniture making]], [[glass]] or [[glassblowing]], [[clay]] or [[ceramic]]s, [[textiles]], [[metal]] or [[metalworking]]. Studio craft works tend to either serve or allude to a functional or utilitarian purpose, though they are as often as not handled and exhibited in ways similar to visual art objects.
==History== The American studio craft movement is a successor to earlier European craft movements. Modern studio crafts developed as a reaction to [[modernity]] and, particularly, the [[Industrial Revolution]]. During the nineteenth century, Scottish historian [[Thomas Carlyle]] and English social critic [[John Ruskin]] warned of the extinction of [[handicrafts]] in [[Europe]]. English designer and theorist [[William Morris]] continued this line of thought, becoming father of [[England's]] [[Arts & Crafts Movement]]. Morris distinguished the studio craftsman in this way: "[O]ur art is the work of a small minority composed of educated persons, fully conscious of their aim of producing beauty, and distinguished from the great body of workmen by that aim." Both European and American craft traditions have also been influenced by [[Art Nouveau]]. Both of these movements influenced the development of the contemporary studio craft movement in the [[United States]] during the late nineteenth century, throughout the twentieth century and to the present.
==American craft pioneers== [[File:Tiffany Window of St Augustine - Lightner Museum.jpg|left|border|thumb|[[Louis Comfort Tiffany]], Window of [[Augustine of Hippo|St. Augustine]], in the [[Lightner Museum]], [[St. Augustine, Florida]]]] In the early nineteenth century it became popular for rural Americans of modest means to take the decoration of their homes and furniture into their own hands. The artist [[Rufus Porter (inventor)|Rufus Porter]] was an early proponent of the American craft movement. In 1825 he published ''A Select Collection of Valuable and Curious Arts, and Interesting Experiments Which are Well Explained, and Warranted Genuine, and May be Prepared, Safely and at Little Expense'', which is a book of instructions for domestic decorative arts, including wall, floor, and furniture painting.
By the end of the nineteenth century, the preindustrial craft trades had almost disappeared. Industrial expansion and westward movement had largely severed American culture from early Colonial American and Native American craft roots. Against this backdrop, [[Louis Comfort Tiffany]] was a pioneer of the American craft movement, arguing for the placement of well-designed and crafted objects in the American home. Tiffany's elegant [[stained glass]] creations were influenced by the values of [[William Morris]] and became America's leading embodiment of [[art nouveau]].
{{main|Gustav Stickley}} [[Gustav Stickley]], the [[cabinetmaker]] was an early leader in the development of [[Studio Furniture]] and the American craft movement. Stickley's designs were distinguished by their simplicity and by their harmony between interior [[decorative art]] and [[architecture]]. Stickley's magazine, "[[The Craftsman (magazine)|The Craftsman]]," was a forum for this movement from 1901 through 1916. Originally focused on expounding ideas from the [[England]]'s [[Arts and Crafts Movement]], "The Craftsman" increasingly developed American craft concepts over the years of its publication. Stickley's ideas later had influence on [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] and future generations of American craftsmen, artists and architects.
The [[Roycroft]] movement was an American adaptation of the British arts and crafts movement founded by [[Elbert Hubbard]] and his wife [[Bertha Crawford Hubbard]] in the small-town of [[East Aurora, New York]] in 1895. Its focus was on writing and publishing ornate books, but it also made furniture and metal products. Roycroft was organized as a living/working artisans' community along the lines of a [[Medieval]] European [[guild]].
==Early craft institutions== The studio crafts movement was fostered by the establishment of crafts programs within post-secondary educational institutions. In 1894, for example, North America's first [[university]] [[Ceramics (art)|ceramics]] department was begun at [[Ohio State University]] in [[Columbus, Ohio]]. This was followed in 1901 by the establishment of the first ceramics art school at [[Alfred University]] in [[Alfred (village), New York|Alfred, New York]]. Similarly, the [[Rhode Island School of Design]] in [[Providence, Rhode Island]] established the first metal arts class in 1901 and the first textiles class in 1903.
After World War I, a postwar spirit of internationalism influenced the establishment of other important craft institutions, such as the [[Cranbrook Academy of Art]] in [[Bloomfield Hills, Michigan]]. Cranbrook craftsmen translated organic and geometric forms into the style that would be known as [[Art Deco]]. At Cranbrook, teachers like [[Maija Grotell]] produced important work in their own right while also teaching a new generation of young studio craft artists.
==The Depression years and World War II== During the [[Great Depression|Depression]] years, the federal Works Progress Administration funded crafts projects as well as public works and murals as a way to both keep workers working and as a way to increase national morale. This enabled crafts to flourish at a local level. At the same time, American art programs began to include craft studies into their curricula.
[[World War II]] brought an influx of European artists and craftsmen. These European exiles brought with them a range of historical traditions including not only European craft practices but also knowledge of Asian and other non-Western cultures. One example of this influx is Tage Frid, a Danish furniture maker, who established the reputation of the Furniture Making program at Rhode Island School of Design, and there are certainly others. Also during the post World War II period a general dissatisfaction with industrial society began to fuel further support for handmade art objects. In 1943, the [[American Craft Council]] was founded to support craftspeople and cultivate an appreciation for their work. The ACC's founder, [[Aileen Osborn Webb]] was a potter interested in creating marketing opportunities for studio craftsmen. The organization eventually grew to include [[American Craft (magazine)|''American Craft'']] magazine and the [[Museum of Arts and Design]] (then called the Museum of Contemporary Crafts and at one point known as the American Craft Museum). As a result of these phenomena, post-war American craft became stylistically more refined as well as technically more proficient.
==The 1950s and Peter Voulkos== {{main|Peter Voulkos}} [[File:Voulkos-Balistreri.jpg|thumb|left|[[Peter Voulkos]] (left) assisted by [[John Balistreri]].]]During the 1950s, some artists turned to the '''[[truth-to-materials]]''' doctrine. This movement also entailed an emphasis on the collective production of crafts work. Craftsmen sometimes worked together during this period to develop more ambitious projects. Throughout the 1950s and afterwards, [[Pottery|potter]] [[Peter Voulkos]] developed increasingly largescale and nontraditional [[ceramic]] works, influenced by [[Abstract Expressionism]], which transformed traditional understandings of the [[craft]] media. Like the [[Abstract Expressionists]], Voulkos emphasized performance, process and primal expression in his ceramic forms. In some cases, Voulkos deconstructed and reconstructed traditional ceramic [[Bowl (vessel)|vessel]] forms such as plates, ice buckets, and [[tea bowls]]. In other works, Voulkos created new nonutilitarian forms, such as his purely sculptural, large-scale cylindrical "stacks."
Voulkos was also influenced by [[Zen Buddhism]] after a 1952 encounter with Japanese potter [[Shoji Hamada]]. Hamada encouraged Voulkos to embrace a Zen approach to ceramics based not only upon technical proficiency but also upon a mental and spiritual union between creator and art object. Voulkos later cited Hamada's statement that it "took him ten years to learn the potter's wheel and another ten years to forget it"—an insight that inspired Voulkos' early attempts to fully form a teapot in two minutes.<ref>Timothy Anglin Burgard, The Art of Craft: Contemporary Works from the Saxe Collection, [[Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco]], 1999 at 13</ref>
Voulkos taught at [[Black Mountain College]] in 1953, where he was further exposed to the [[avant-garde]] movements. In 1954, he founded the [[Ceramics (art)|ceramics]] department at the [[Otis College of Art and Design]] (then called the Los Angeles County Art Institute). In [[California]], Voulkos' [[pottery]] rapidly became abstract and sculptural. Voulkos then moved to the [[University of California, Berkeley]], where he founded another [[Ceramics (art)|ceramics]] department and taught from 1959 until 1985. At Berkeley, Voulkos became increasingly prominent for his massive, cracked and slashed pots.
==The 1960s and the new glassblowing movement== The culture of the 1960s was even more conducive to the development of studio crafts. This period saw a rejection of [[materialism]] and exploration of alternative ways of living. For some, the creation of [[handicrafts]] provided just such an outlet. In 1962, then-[[Ceramics (art)|ceramics]] professor [[Harvey Littleton]] and chemist [[Dominick Labino]] began the contemporary [[glassblowing]] movement. The impetus for the movement consisted of their two workshops at the [[Toledo Museum of Art]], during which they began experimenting with melting glass in a small furnace and creating blown glass art. Thus Littleton and Labino were the first to make molten glass feasible for artists in private studios. [[Harvey Littleton]] extended his influence through his own important artistic contributions and through his teaching.<ref>[http://www.cmog.org/dynamic.aspx?id=1792 The Corning Museum of Glass. "Decades in Glass: The '60s."]</ref> Over the years, [[Harvey Littleton]] trained many of the most important contemporary glass artists, including [[Marvin Lipofsky]], Sam Herman (Britain), Fritz Dreisbach and [[Dale Chihuly]]. These Littleton students in turn developed the new movement and spread it across the country. [[Marvin Lipofsky]], for example, is credited with being one of the founders of the [[Glass Art Society]] and introducing studio glass to California. In 1967, Lipofsky founded the glass program at the [[California College of Arts and Crafts]], which he headed for two decades.
In 1971, [[Dale Chihuly]] began the influential [[Pilchuck Glass School]] near the rural town of [[Stanwood, Washington]]. Influenced by the [[Haystack Mountain School of Crafts]] (the first school to have a glass furnace), and the [[Penland School of Crafts]], [[Pilchuck Glass School]] has become a center of the contemporary American [[studio glass movement]], of which Chihuly is a leading figure. Artist [[Toots Zynsky]], a Pilchuck pioneer, observed that the choice of a Western location for the school reflected a conscious rejection of the Eastern art establishment. The naming of the school also reflected the founders' countercultural attraction to [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] culture. Chihuly chose the name "Pilchuck," derived from the [[Chinookan]] words for "red" and "water," alluding to the iron-rich waters of the nearby [[Pilchuck River]].
==The Renwick Gallery== {{main|Renwick Gallery}} [[File:RenwickGallery.jpg|left|thumb|border]] In 1972, the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[Renwick Gallery]] was founded as a studio craft department of the [[National Museum of American Art]]. Housed in the original [[Corcoran Gallery of Art]] building across [[Pennsylvania Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Pennsylvania Avenue]] from the [[White House]], it provided a distinguished setting for American studio craft objects in [[Washington, D.C.]]
==The Year of American Craft== In 1992, [[President of the United States|President]] [[George H. W. Bush]] signed a proclamation designating 1993 as '''The Year of American Craft'''. As part of this commemoration, [[Renwick Gallery]] director Michael Monroe selected seventy-two works by seventy American craftsmen which were donated to the [[White House]] to serve as [[The White House Collection of American Crafts]]. This collection was displayed for four months at the [[National Museum of American Art]] in 1995.
== See also == {{list-columns|colwidth=22em| * [[American Craftsman]] * [[American Fancy]] * [[Appalachian Spring (store)]] * [[Applied art]] * [[Art nouveau]] * [[Art quilts]] * [[Art deco]] * [[Handicrafts|Arts and crafts]] * [[Blacksmithing]] * [[Ceramics (art)|Ceramics]] * [[Craft]] * [[Decorative arts]] * [[Fiber art]] * [[Glass art]] * [[Glass blowing]] * [[Handicraft]] * [[History of decorative art]] * [[Mosaic]] * [[Quilt]] * [[Studio Craft]] * [[Studio Furniture]] * [[Studio pottery]] * [[Woodturning]] }}
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *Biography.com ''[http://www.biography.com/search/article.do?id=9520690 Peter Voulkos Biography (1924–2002)]'' (Retrieved 2007-09-01) *Timothy Anglin Burgard, The Art of Craft: Contemporary Works from the Saxe Collection. [[Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco]], 1999. {{ISBN|0-88401-098-8}} (paperback). {{ISBN|0-8212-2637-1}} (hardcover). * Barbaralee Diamonstein, "Values, Skills and Dreams: Crafts in America", in Michael Monroe, The White House Collection of American Crafts, [[Harry N. Abrams, Inc.]] 1995. {{ISBN|0-8109-4035-3}}. * Julie Hall, Tradition and Change: The New American Craftsman, [[E.P. Dutton]], 1977. {{ISBN|0-525-22195-6}}. * Kenneth Trapp and Howard Risatti, Skilled Work: American Craft in the Renwick Gallery. Smithsonian Institution Press, 1998. {{ISBN|1-56098-806-1}} * Pohl, Francis K. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070808010902/http://www.thamesandhudsonusa.com/new/fall02/523792.htm Framing America]. A Social History of American Art. New York: Thames and Hudson, 2002 (pages 118-122)
==External links== [[File:06-02-12 Bennett.Bean.jpg|thumb|left|[[Bennett Bean]]'s painted pots]] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110717111941/http://www.americancraftmag.org/ American Craft magazine] *[http://www.davinandkesler.com/ American crafts ] *[http://www.craftcouncil.org/ American Craft Council] *[http://americanart.si.edu/renwick/ Renwick Gallery official website] *[http://www.redefiningcraft.com/ Redefining Craft] *[http://www.AmericanStyle.com/ AmericanStyle magazine] *[http://www.madmuseum.org/ Museum of Arts and Design] *[http://www.bergpublishers.com/JournalsHomepage/TheJournalofModernCraft/tabid/3254/Default.aspx/ The Journal of Modern Craft] *[http://www.sofaexpo.com/ International Expositions of Sculpture Objects and Functional Art, Chicago and New York] *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/search/collection/p15324coll10/searchterm/American%20furniture%20in%20the%20Metropolitan%20Museum%20of%20Art/field/title/mode/exact/conn/and/order/nosort ''American Furniture in The Metropolitan Museum of Art''], a fully digitized 2 volume exhibition catalog
