{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Diana_MSG.jpg | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 240px | title = Diana (second version) | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Augustus Saint-Gaudens]] | year = 1892-1893 | type = copper sheeting | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 14.5 | height_inch = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[Philadelphia]] | museum = [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]] | coordinates = | owner = }}
'''''Diana''''' – also known as '''''Diana of the Tower''''' – is an [[Cultural icon|iconic]] statue by sculptor [[Augustus Saint-Gaudens]]. Once a famous New York City landmark, the second version stood atop the tower of [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|Madison Square Garden]] from 1893 to 1925. Since 1932, it has been in the collection of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]].
The statue represents the goddess [[Diana (mythology)|Diana]].
==First version (1891-1892)== ''Diana'' was commissioned by architect [[Stanford White]] as a [[weather vane]] for the tower of Madison Square Garden, a theater-and-dining complex at [[26th Street (Manhattan)|26th Street]] and [[Madison Avenue]] in Manhattan. He talked his friend Saint-Gaudens into creating it at no charge, and picked up the cost of materials.<ref name="auto">"The Architect of Desire: Beauty and Danger in the Stanford White Family," Suzanna Lessard</ref> Model Julia "Dudie" Baird posed for the body of the statue.<ref>http://www.sgnhs.org/Augustus%20SGaudens%20CD-HTML/Models/Dudie.htm</ref> Its face is that of Davida Johnson Clark, Saint-Gaudens's long-time model and mother of his illegitimate son Louis.<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search/17571 Davida Johnson Clark], from Metropolitan Museum of Art.</ref>
The first version – built by the [[W. H. Mullins Manufacturing Company]] in [[Salem, Ohio]] – was {{convert|18|ft|m|abbr=on}} tall and weighed {{convert|1800|lb|abbr=on}}.<ref>http://www.sgnhs.org/Augustus%20SGaudens%20CD-HTML/Monuments/Ideal/Diana1.htm</ref> Saint-Gaudens's design specified that the figure appear to delicately balance on its left toe atop a ball. However, the Ohio metal shop was unable to pass the rotating rod through the toe, so the design was altered and the figure instead was poised (less-gracefully) on its heel.
''Diana'' was unveiled atop Madison Square Garden's tower on September 29, 1891. The 304-foot (92.66 m) building had been completed a year earlier, and was the second-tallest in New York City. But the addition of the statue made it the city's tallest, by 13 feet (3.96 m).<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=JVzYO1TyZ6AC&pg=PA157&lpg=PA157&dq=madison+square+garden+tower+height&source=bl&ots=yk6wC1Fcyd&sig=mHLM8zLgVHCygH_8JP3I35PvQak&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEMQ6AEwBmoVChMIy-ydxsf5yAIVCmg-Ch26cwHp#v=onepage&q=madison%20square%20garden%20tower%20height&f=false Joseph J. Korum, ''The American Skyscraper, 1850–1940'' (2008)]</ref> The figure's billowing copper [[foulard]] (scarf) was intended to catch the wind, but the statue did not rotate smoothly because of its weight. ''Diana''{{'}}s nudity offended [[morality|moral crusader]] [[Anthony Comstock]] and his [[New York Society for the Suppression of Vice]].<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s9l5TIzarCUC&pg=PT61&dq=american+eve+the+statue&hl=en&ei=iYm5TtDtMaOQsALkvejZCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false| title=American Eve: Evelyn Nesbit, Stanford White, the Birth of the "It" Girl, and the Crime of the Century | author= Paula Uruburu| publisher= Penguin| year= 2009| isbn= 978-1-59448-369-1}}</ref> To placate Comstock and to increase the likelihood of its catching the wind, Saint-Gaudens draped the figure in cloth, but the cloth blew away.<ref>Federal Writers' Project. ''New York City Guide''. New York: Random House, 1939 {{ISBN|0-403-02921-X}} (Reprinted by Scholarly Press, 1976; often referred to as WPA Guide to New York City), pp.330–333</ref>
Soon after installation, both White and Saint-Gaudens concluded that the figure was too large for the building, and decided to create a smaller, lighter replacement. Following less than a year atop the tower, the statue was removed and shipped to Chicago to be exhibited at the 1893 [[World's Columbian Exposition]]. New Yorker W. T. Henderson wrote a [[tongue-in-cheek]] poetic tribute – "Diana Off the Tower" – a play on both the statue's name and situation.<ref>W. T. Henderson, [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1892/09/18/106890362.pdf "Diana Off the Tower" (PDF),] ''The New York Times'', September 18, 1892.</ref>
Saint-Gaudens served as head of the Chicago exposition's sculpture committee. His initial plan had been to place ''Diana'' atop the Women's Pavilion, but the city's [[Women's Christian Temperance Union]] protested and insisted that the controversial nude figure be clothed.<ref name="auto"/> Instead, it was placed atop the Agricultural Building.
The original ''Diana'' does not survive. In June 1894, eight months after the exposition's closing, a major fire tore through its buildings. The lower half of the statue was destroyed; the upper half survived the fire, but was later lost or discarded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jssgallery.org/other_artists/augustus_saint-gaudens/diana_of_the_tower.html|title=Augustus Saint-Gaudens' Diana of the Tower|first=|last=Natasha|publisher=}}</ref> <gallery> File:Davida Johnson Clark by Saint-Gaudens 1886.jpg|''Bust of Davida Johnson Clark'' (1886) by Saint-Gaudens. File:Diana 1st Version.jpg|First version of ''Diana'' in the foundry of the W. H. Mullins Manufacturing Company, Salem, Ohio, 1891. File:Agricultural Building (3572762953).jpg|Atop the Agriculture Building, World's Columbian Exposition, Chicago, 1893. </gallery>
==Second version (1893-present)== [[File:Madison Square Garden Diana.jpg|thumb|right|Second version of ''Diana'' with her copper foulard.]] ''Diana'' was completely redesigned by Saint-Gaudens – with a more elegant pose, a different thrust to the body, a thinner figure, smaller breasts and a more graceful angle to the leg. To better fit the proportions of Madison Square Garden's tower, the statue's height was scaled down to 14.5 feet (4.4 m).<ref>The Philadelphia Museum of Art's website lists the height of the figure as 13 ft 1 in (398.8 cm), and the height of the ball as 17 in (43 cm).[http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/44513.html?mulR=241195760|1]</ref> The second version was made of hollowed copper, and weighed 700 lb (318 kg) – more than 60% less than the first version – light enough to rotate with the wind. As Saint-Gaudens originally envisioned, the figure was balanced on its left toe atop a ball. The statue was hoisted to the top of the tower on November 18, 1893.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1893/11/18/109733483.pdf| title=New Diana of the Tower| work=The New York Times| date=November 18, 1893}}</ref>
During the day, the gilded figure caught the sun and could be seen from all over the city and as far away as New Jersey. Electric lights, then a novelty, illuminated it at night; it was the first statue in history to be lit by electricity.<ref>http://www.sgnhs.org/Augustus%20SGaudens%20CD-HTML/Monuments/Ideal/Diana2.htm</ref>
Madison Square Garden was slated to be demolished in 1925, to make way for construction of the [[New York Life Building]]. Prior to the building's demolition, ''Diana'' was removed and put in storage. The intention was for the statue to remain in New York City, however a seven year search to find a place to display it proved futile. In 1932, the [[New York Life Insurance Company]] presented ''Diana'' to the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]] as a gift. It remains there today, displayed on the balcony of the museum's Great Stair Hall.<ref>[http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/44513.html?mulR=967189961|8 Object record] in the Philadelphia Museum of Art's online collection.</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Philadelphia Museum greatstairhall.jpg| thumb|left|Saint-Gauden's second version of "Diana" on display in the Great Stair Hall of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]]. This is the same statue that sat atop Madison Square Garden from 1893 until the building was demolished in 1925.{{Deletable image-caption|date=May 2012}}]] -->
===Restoration=== [[File:Diana of the Tower Philadelphia Museum of Art cropped.jpg|thumb|left|Second version of ''Diana'' (restored, 2013-14), Philadelphia Museum of Art.]] When ''Diana'' was removed from Madison Square Garden in 1925, much of its gilded exterior was gone, having eroded away over three decades of exposure to the elements. The Philadelphia Museum of Art cleaned and repaired the statue in 1932, but the gold leaf was not replaced.
In 2013, scaffolding was constructed around the statue in the museum's Great Stair Hall for a year-long restoration. Conservators carefully cleaned its copper surface with chemicals and steam, removing nearly a century of dirt and grime. Samples of the small patches of remaining gold leaf on the statue were taken in an effort to match the carat, weight and color with its replacement. The statue's surface was then repaired and regilded with 180 square feet of gold leaf. Because it was known from contemporary sources that Saint-Gaudens did not like the look of bright gold at eye level, the conservators matted the gilding to reduce the glare and museum lighting designers adjusted the display lights for the interior display.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philamuseum.org/conservation/21.html|title=Philadelphia Museum of Art - Research : Conservation|first=Philadelphia Museum of|last=Art|publisher=}}</ref>
On July 14, 2014, the restored statue was unveiled and rededicated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-2687882/Philadelphia-museums-golden-goddess-glows-again.html#ixzz3mOfi0n9r|title=Philadelphia museum's golden goddess glows again|publisher=}}</ref>
===Cultural references===
In the popular 1975 novel ''[[Ragtime (novel)|Ragtime]]'', author [[E.L. Doctorow]] suggests in a single line that showgirl [[Evelyn Nesbitt]] had posed for the second version of the ''Diana'' statue. Having grown up poor in the streets of a Pennsylvania coal town, Nesbitt had risen up to become “the Gaudens statue Stanny White had put at the top of the tower of Madison Square Garden, a glorious bronze nude Diana, her bow drawn, her face in the skies.”
The 1981 film version of [[Ragtime (film)|''Ragtime'']] expanded upon this incident as the cause of a major conflict between Stanford White and Nesbitt's millionaire husband [[Harry K. Thaw]]. In the film, Thaw demands that the statue be taken down from the top of the Garden as it is an embarrassment to him. The character is seen glaring angrily at the statue before shooting White to death at the Rooftop Theatre at [[Madison Square Garden (1890)|Madison Square Garden]] on June 25, 1906.
Both situations are completely fictional. The second version of ''Diana'' was placed atop the tower in 1893, when Nesbitt was only about nine years old, and eight years before she was introduced to White. {{clear}}
==Other versions==
===Half-sized statues=== [[File:Swanson4715.jpg|thumb|Half-sized ''Diana'' (1928), [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].]] [[Stanford White]] was so pleased with the 1893 second version that he asked Saint-Gaudens to create a half-sized copy in cement. This was installed in 1894 in the garden of White's Long Island estate, [[Box Hill Estate|Box Hill]], where it stood for many years. For the half-sized copy, Saint-Gaudens poised the figure on a half-ball. White's cement statue later was used to produce two bronze casts in 1928, and six bronze casts in 1987.<ref>John H. Dryfhout, ''The Works of Augustus Saint-Gaudens'' (UPNE, 2008), cat. 154, p. 207.</ref> The cement statue is now in the collection of the [[Amon Carter Museum of American Art]].<ref>[http://artmuseum.princeton.edu/collections/objects/33417 Diana], from Princeton University Art Museum.</ref> * [[Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site]], plaster. Saint-Gaudens's 1894 model. * Amon Carter Museum of American Art, cement. Stanford White's 1894 copy. * 1928 casts ** [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], gilded bronze ** Bass Hall, Fort Worth, Texas, bronze * 1987 casts ** [[Madison Square Garden]], New York City, bronze ** [[Brookgreen Gardens]], bronze<ref>http://www.brookgreen.org/AugustusSaint-Gaudens.cfm</ref> ** [[Princeton University Art Museum]], bronze<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!420595~!22&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 Diana (Princeton University)], from SIRIS.</ref> ** Private collection, Saint-James, New York, bronze ** Private collection, Chicago, Illinois, bronze ** Private collection, Santa Fe, New Mexico, bronze
===Statuettes=== [[File:Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site SAGA2182.jpg|thumb|Statuette (foreground) and half-sized plaster model (background), [[Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site]].]] The [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] owns a bronze statuette of Saint-Gaudens's first version of ''Diana''.<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!293600~!11&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 ''Diana'' (first version)], from SIRIS.</ref>
Capitalizing on the popularity of the second version, Saint-Gaudens modeled statuettes in two sizes: 31 inches (78 cm), with the figure poised on a half-ball, and 21 inches (53 cm), with the figure poised on a full ball. These were cast in bronze beginning in 1899, and vary in the configuration of bow, arrow, string, hair, patination, and base.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/1985.353|title=Diana - Augustus Saint-Gaudens - 1985.353 - Work of Art - Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History - The Metropolitan Museum of Art|publisher=}}</ref> * [[National Gallery of Art]], bronze<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nga.gov/collection/sculpture/noflash/zone1-3.htm|title=NGA Sculpture Galleries|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], bronze * [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]], bronze<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/diana-saint-gaudens-augustus|title=Diana|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=L320778B70P25.61742&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!26038~!124&ri=4&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=saint+gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=4&limitbox_1=LO01+=+ias#focus ''Diana'', (sculpture)]. ''SIRIS''</ref> * [[Cleveland Museum of Art]], bronze<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=L320778B70P25.61742&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!12453~!117&ri=4&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=saint+gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=4&limitbox_1=LO01+=+ias#focus ''Diana'', (sculpture)]. ''SIRIS''</ref> * [[Williams College Museum of Art]], bronze * Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site, bronze * [[New York Historical Society]], bronze * [[Brooklyn Museum]], bronze<ref>[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/259/Diana_of_the_Tower Diana of the Tower], from Brooklyn Museum.</ref> * other museum and private collections.
===Busts and heads=== In 1908, the sculptor's widow authorized a posthumous casting of nine busts based on Saint-Gaudens's 31-inch (78 cm) statuette.<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=1446K2BT31887.1258&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!349897~!16&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 Diana (bust)], from SIRIS.</ref> A 7-3/8 in (18.7 cm) plaster bust is at Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site. Bronze busts are at the [[Carnegie Museum of Art]],<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!12723~!5&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 ''Diana of the Tower'' (bust)], from SIRIS.</ref> and in private collections.
Bronze casts of ''Diana'' 's head are at Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site;<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=L320778B70P25.61742&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!18560~!114&ri=4&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=saint+gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=4&limitbox_1=LO01+=+ias#focus Diana, (head)], from SIRIS.</ref> [[Harvard University]];<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=14467JO08361U.605&profile=ariall&source=~!siartinventories&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=3100001~!10490~!1&ri=1&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Saint-Gaudens&index=.AW&uindex=&oper=&term=Diana&index=.TW&uindex=&aspect=Keyword&menu=search&ri=1 Head of Diana], from SIRIS.</ref> and elsewhere.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Diana (Saint-Gaudens)}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZ7dTBhL3oI&safety_mode=true&persist_safety_mode=1 PBS Documentary – ''Augustus Saint-Gaudens: Master of American Sculpture – The Diana'' ] *Jennifer Hardin, [http://hoodmuseum.dartmouth.edu/av/americanartatdartmouth/diana.html "Augustus Saint-Gaudens's ''Diana'' of 1891–93: Critical and Public Response to a Singular American Nude"], Hood Museum *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/34389/rec/62 ''Augustus Saint-Gaudens, Master Sculptor''], exhibition catalog fully online as PDF from The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which contains material on ''Diana''
{{Augustus Saint-Gaudens}}

revision.comment: legal name of the company is Dribbble Holdings Ltd., I don't know Tiny legal name
revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = Dribbble | logo =File:Dribbble Text Logo Script.svg | screenshot = | screenshot_size = | caption = | screenshot_alt = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | url = {{URL|https://www.dribbble.com}} | slogan = | commercial = Yes | type = | registration = | language = English | num_users = | content_license = | owner = Dribbble Holdings Ltd. (direct owner)
[http://tiny.website/ Tiny] | author = Founders: Dan Cederholm and Rich Thornett CEO: Zack Onisko | editor = | launch_date = | revenue = | alexa = {{decrease}} 1165 ({{as of|2017|11|28|alt=November 2017}}){{cite web|title=dribbble.com Site Overview|url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/dribbble.com|website=Alexa|publisher=[[Alexa Internet]]|accessdate=28 November 2017}} | ip = | current_status = Up | footnotes = | programming_language = | Company Worth = }} '''Dribbble''' is an [[community|online community]] for showcasing user-made [[Work of art|artwork]]. It functions as a [[Promotion (marketing)|self-promotion]] and [[Business networking|networking]] platform for [[graphic design]], [[web design]], [[illustration]], [[photography]], and other creative areas. It was founded in 2009 by [[Dan Cederholm]] and [[Rich Thornett]], becoming publicly available in 2010. It is one of the largest platforms for designers to share their work online{{Cite news|url=https://dribbble.com/stories/2017/01/23/2016-year-in-review|title=2016 Year in Review|work=Dribbble|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en}} competing directly with [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]]-owned [[Behance]] — the latter being the largest.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/anthonykosner/2013/05/07/adobes-behance-the-creative-graph-lets-your-work-do-the-networking/|title=Adobe's Behance: The Creative Graph Lets Your Work Do The Networking|last=Kosner|first=Anthony Wing|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en}} The company is fully remote with no central headquarters.{{Cite web|url=https://www.getflow.com/blog/project-management-at-dribbble|title=How Dribbble’s 23 Remote Employees Keep Half a Million Designers…|last=|first=|date=2018-06-27|website=Flow|language=en-us|others=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-28}} Dribbble became a part of Tiny, a family of internet startup companies, in January 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://dribbble.com/stories/2017/01/17/transition-game|title=Transition Game|work=Dribbble|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@awilkinson/dribbble-2-0-c2cd1fa184c5|title=Dribbble 2.0|last=Wilkinson|first=Andrew|date=2017-01-17|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-28}} ==Membership and Controversy== Dribbble has an [[Invitation system|invite-only]] membership system, where a number of invitations are handed out to artists and designers to freely distribute them amongst their peers. There is also a Pro subscription service with added features.{{cite web|url=https://dribbble.com/pro|title=Dribbble - Show and tell for designers|author=|date=|work=dribbble.com}} There have been discussions around their invite-only membership system, which has caused some controversy. The system has been used as a way to control the growth of the platform.{{Cite news|url=https://www.webdesignerdepot.com/2011/05/interview-with-dribbbles-founder-dan-cederholm/|title=Interview with Dribbble's co-founder Dan Cederholm|last=|first=|date=2011-05-24|work=Webdesigner Depot|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en}} Upon joining the website the user is first listed as a ''Prospect'', only being able to effectively post work once they get an invitation from another user. This has provoked debate amongst the design community, often describing it as a form of [[elitism]].{{cite web|url=http://www.webdesignerdepot.com/2013/11/the-ultimate-guide-to-everything-dribbble/|title=The ultimate guide to everything Dribbble|author=|date=|work=Webdesigner Depot}}{{Cite news|url=https://thenextweb.com/dd/2011/03/29/dribbble-one-year-on-does-it-live-up-to-the-hype/|title=Dribbble, one year on: does it live up to the hype?|last=Gamache|first=Dave|date=2011-03-29|work=The Next Web|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@sodevious/design-dribbble-and-greatness-57bd364c4929|title=Design, Dribbble and Greatness|last=Dominguez|first=Nicole|date=2013-08-26|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-28}} ==Features== In October 2014, Dribbble announced a feature which allows users sharing work that is also for sale to link to sites for purchase.{{Cite news|url=http://blog.dribbble.com/2014/10/24/goods.html|title=Good News|work=Dribbble|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en}} On 17 May 2016, Playbook was released. Playbook is an instant portfolio with simple and light customization, powered by Dribbble, at your own domain or on dribbble.com. The Playbook feature is a paid service, that is charged annually.{{Cite web|url = https://dribbble.com/shots/2720205-Introducing-Playbook|title = Introducing Playbook|date = May 17, 2016|accessdate = |website = Dribbble|publisher = |last = |first = }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official Website}} [[Category:Art websites]] [[Category:Companies based in Salem, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2009]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Driving Miss Daisy | image = Driving Miss Daisy 2014 poster.jpg | caption = | director = [[David Esbjornson]]
Peter Ots | producer = [[Jill Bilcock]]
Richard Moore | writer = [[Alfred Uhry]] | starring = [[Angela Lansbury]]
[[James Earl Jones]]
[[Boyd Gaines]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = Broadway Near You
[[Umbrella Entertainment]] | distributor = Omniverse Vision (UK)
[[Screenvision]] (North America)
[[Fathom Events]] (US) | released = {{Film date|2014|05|25|UK|2014|06|04|North America|2014|08|02|Australia}} | runtime = 90 minutes | country = United States
Australia | language = English }} '''''Driving Miss Daisy''''' is a filmed performance of the 2013 [[Australia]]n [[theatrical production]] of the [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning [[Driving Miss Daisy (play)|play of the same name]] by [[Alfred Uhry]] starring [[Angela Lansbury]], [[James Earl Jones]] and [[Boyd Gaines]] which was produced as a 2014 film by Broadway Near You (United States) in association with [[Umbrella Entertainment]] (Australia). ==Synopsis== Miss Daisy Werthan ([[Angela Lansbury]]) is a widowed, 72-year-old Jewish woman living in mid-century [[Atlanta]] who is deemed too old to drive by her son Boolie ([[Boyd Gaines]]). He then hires Hoke, an African-American man ([[James Earl Jones]]) to serve as her chauffeur, and what begins as a troubled and hostile pairing soon blossoms into a profound, life-altering friendship that transcends all the societal boundaries placed between them. ==Cast== *[[Angela Lansbury]] as Miss Daisy Werthan *[[Boyd Gaines]] as Boolie Werthan *[[James Earl Jones]] as Hoke ==Production background== The Australian tour of the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of ''Driving Miss Daisy'' performed to sold-out audiences in [[Brisbane]], [[Sydney]], [[Melbourne]], [[Adelaide]] and [[Perth]] from February 9 to June 16, 2013.Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/stage-version-of-driving-miss-daisy-starring-angela-lansbury-and-james-earl-214126# "Stage Version of Driving Miss Daisy, Starring Angela Lansbury and James Earl Jones, Filmed for Distribution"] Playbill, January 24, 2014 James Earl Jones and Boyd Gaines, who originally starred in the play's [[Driving Miss Daisy (play)#Broadway .282010.E2.80.932011.29|2010 Broadway revival]] and subsequent [[Driving Miss Daisy (play)#West End revival .282011.29|2011 West End transfer]] (opposite [[Vanessa Redgrave]]), both reprised their Broadway roles for the Australian tour. This performance of the play was filmed with six cameras in [[high-definition video]] during its successful five-week run at [[Comedy Theatre, Melbourne|The Comedy Theatre]] in [[Melbourne|Melbourne, Australia]] from April 5 to May 12, 2013. A local crew was used for the six-camera shoot and Melbourne-based independent company Soundfirm completed all post-production – picture and sound.[http://www.soundfirm.com/featuredcredit/driving-miss-daisy/ ''Driving Miss Daisy'': Soundfirm post-production] The production of ''Driving Miss Daisy'', directed for the stage by [[David Esbjornson]] and directed for the screen by Peter Ots, was filmed by New York's Broadway Near You in association with Australia's [[Umbrella Entertainment]] and produced by [[Jill Bilcock]] and Richard Moore. The play was produced for the Australian stage by John Frost by special arrangement with [[Jed Bernstein]] and [[Adam Zotovich]]. The creative team included [[John Lee Beatty]] (Scenic Design), [[Peter Kaczorowski]] (Lighting Design), [[Wendall K. Harrington]] (Projection Design), Christopher Cronin (Sound Design) and Mark Bennett (Composer). ==Theatrical release and broadcast== ===Theatrical=== On May 25, 2014, a special one-off screening of ''Driving Miss Daisy: The Play'' was broadcast live via satellite from [[BFI Southbank]] in [[London]] to over 300 cinemas across the [[United Kingdom]] followed by an onstage [[FAQ|Q&A session]] with [[Angela Lansbury]], presented by Omniverse Vision in association with BFI.[http://www.bfi.org.uk/sites/bfi.org.uk/files/downloads/bfi-press-release-driving-miss-daisy-angela-lansbury-2014-03-31.pdf BFI press release: ''Driving Miss Daisy: The Play'' plus Q&A with Angela Lansbury], March 31, 2014. On June 4, 2014, ''Driving Miss Daisy'' was released in a limited theatrical engagement in more than 500 movie theaters across the [[United States]] and [[Canada]], presented by [[Screenvision]] in association with Broadway Near You.[http://www.broadway.com/buzz/175840/driving-miss-daisy-starring-angela-lansbury-james-earl-jones-will-hit-movie-theaters-nationwide-this-summer/ ''Driving Miss Daisy'', Starring Angela Lansbury & James Earl Jones, Will Hit Movie Theaters Nationwide This Summer]. ''[[Key Brand Entertainment|broadway.com]]'', May 8, 2014. On August 2, 2014, ''Driving Miss Daisy'' was screened at [[Village Cinemas]] in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]] and featured the previously taped Q&A session with Angela Lansbury, followed by an Australian-wide limited release. On May 14, 2015, ''Driving Miss Daisy'' was presented as a one-night only event in U.S. cinemas nationwide by [[Fathom Events]] and Broadway Near You. ===Television=== ''Driving Miss Daisy'' was broadcast nationwide on [[PBS]] stations as a presentation of the ''[[Great Performances]]'' series on Friday, July 17, 2015 at 9 pm.[https://www.pbs.org/wnet/gperf/driving-miss-daisy/4009/ ''Driving Miss Daisy'': About the Play – Premiere date: July 17, 2015]. ''[[PBS]].org'' ==Critical review== The Australian stage production was met with critical acclaim. In its 5 star review, ''[[Herald Sun|The Herald Sun]]'' said, "It is a privilege to witness the consummate professionalism and fine acting of two of America's stage and screen royalty, Angela Lansbury and James Earl Jones". ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' critic raved, "I have never been happier jumping out of my chair and applauding wildly, while wiping away moisture from my cheeks". ''The Sydney Season'' praises: "With a cast whose reach transcends generations and whose successes are multitudinous, it is impossible to approach this play without the highest of expectations, and it does not, for a moment, disappoint".[http://www.broadwaynearyou.com/driving-miss-daisy/ ''Driving Miss Daisy'' critical reviews of Australian stage production]. ==DVD release== On August 4, 2015, ''Driving Miss Daisy'' was released on [[DVD]] in [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]] by [[PBS Distribution]], available for purchase exclusively through the official PBS website at ShopPBS.org.[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/DRIVING-MISS-DAISY-Starring-Angela-Lansbury-James-Earl-Jones-Hits-DVD-Today-20150803 ''Driving Miss Daisy'', Starring Angela Lansbury & James Earl Jones, Out on DVD Today]. It was later made available for purchase via [[Amazon (company)|Amazon.com]] as of September 29, 2015. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.playbill.com/article/watch-trailer-for-driving-miss-daisy-starring-angela-lansbury-and-james-earl-jones-video-com-218142}} *{{IMDb title|4653310}} *{{IMDb title|4833010|Driving Miss Daisy: Great Performances}} *{{Amg movie|643031|Driving Miss Daisy}} [[Category:2014 films]] [[Category:2015 television films]] [[Category:2010s comedy-drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American films based on plays]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Plays by Alfred Uhry]] [[Category:Films about old age]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films set in Atlanta]] [[Category:Films shot in Melbourne]] [[Category:Filmed stage productions]] [[Category:PBS network shows]]

[[File:Tomba dei Rilievi (Banditaccia).jpg|thumb|Tomb of the Reliefs at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis]] [[File:Porta-marzia-bn.jpg|thumb|The 2nd-century Porta Marzia at [[Perugia]], its upper part built into a later wall]] [[File:Temple étrusque 2.jpg|thumb|Detail of the Villa Giulia temple reconstruction]]
'''Etruscan architecture''' was created between about 700 BC and 200 BC, when the expanding civilization of [[ancient Rome]] finally absorbed [[Etruscan civilization]]. The Etruscans were considerable builders in stone, wood and other materials of temples, houses, tombs and city walls, as well as bridges and roads. The only structures remaining in quantity in anything like their original condition are tombs and walls, but through archaeology and other sources we have a good deal of information on what once existed.
From about 630 BC, Etruscan architecture was heavily influenced by [[Greek architecture]], which was itself developing through the same period.<ref>Boethius, 34; see Izzet, 20–21 for a discussion of Etruscan cultural importing in general</ref> In turn it influenced [[Roman architecture]], which in its early centuries can be considered as just a regional variation of Etruscan architecture. But increasingly, from about 200 BC, the Romans looked directly to Greece for their styling, while sometimes retaining Etruscan shapes and purposes in their buildings.<ref>Boardman, 220, 255</ref>
The main monumental forms of Etruscan architecture, listed in decreasing order of the surviving remains, were: the houses of the wealthy elite, the mysterious "monumental complexes", temples, city walls, and rock-cut tombs. Apart from the podia of temples and some house foundations, only the walls and rock-cut tombs were mainly in stone, and have therefore often largely survived.<ref>Christofani</ref>
==Temples== The early Etruscans seem to have worshipped in open air enclosures, marked off but not built over; sacrifices continued to be performed outside rather than inside temples in traditional [[Roman religion]] until its end. It was only around 600 BC, at the height of their civilization, that they began to create monumental temples, undoubtedly influenced by the Greeks<ref>Taylor</ref> That these buildings developed essentially from the largest types of Etruscan house has been both asserted and challenged.<ref>Izzet, 19–21</ref>
Usually, only the [[podium]] or base platform used stone, with the upper parts of wood and mud-brick, greatly reducing what survives for archaeologists.<ref>Boethius, 48; Christofani</ref> However, there is evidence for the portico columns sometimes using stone, as at [[Veii]].<ref>Banti, 31–32; Boethius, 59</ref> This has left much about Etruscan temples uncertain. The only written account of significance on their architecture is by [[Vitruvius]] (died after 15 BC), writing some two centuries after the Etruscan civilization was absorbed by Rome. He describes how to plan a "Tuscan temple" that appears to be a Roman "Etruscan-style" ("tuscanicae dispositiones") temple of a type perhaps still sometimes built in his own day, rather than a really historically-minded attempt to describe original Etruscan buildings, though he may well have seen examples of these.<ref>Christofani; Boethius, 33–34</ref>
Many aspects of his description fit what archaeologists can demonstrate, but others do not. It is in any case clear that Etruscan temples could take a number of forms, and also varied over the 400-year period during which they were being made.<ref>Banti, 31–32</ref> Nonetheless Vitruvius remains the inevitable starting point for a description, and a contrast of Etruscan temples with their [[Greek temple|Greek]] and [[Roman temple|Roman]] equivalents. There are also a few model temples in pottery, and depictions on tombs or vases. Remains of the architectural terracotta elements sometimes survive in considerable quantities, and museums, mostly in Italy, have good collections of attractively shaped and painted [[antefix]]es in particular.<ref>Banti, 32</ref>
Vitruvius specifies three doors and three [[cella]]e, one for each of the main Etruscan deities, but archaeological remains do not suggest this was normal, though it is found.<ref>Christofani</ref> Roman sources were in the habit of ascribing to the Etruscans a taste for triads in things such as city planning (with three gates to cities, for example), in ways that do not seem to reflect reality.<ref>Boethius, 35</ref> The orientation of the temple is not consistent, and may have been determined by a priest watching the flight of birds at the time of foundation.<ref>Christofani</ref> [[File:Museo archeologico di Firenze, frontone di Talamone 1.JPG|thumb|left|380px|Late terracotta pediment (part-reconstructed) from [[Talamone]]]] The exteriors of both Greek and Roman temples were originally highly decorated and colourful, especially in the [[entablature]] and roofs, and this was if anything even more true of Etruscan temples. When wood was used for columns, the bases and capitals were often encased in painted terracotta.<ref>Boethius, 59</ref> All the edges of the roof were decorated, mostly in brightly painted terracotta, and there seem often to have been a row of sculptures along the central ridge of the roof, going beyond the [[acroterion]] group above a [[pediment]] in Greek and Roman temples. The [[Apollo of Veii]] was part of an acroterion group.<ref>Boethius, 59–63; Boardman, 255</ref> Substantial but broken remains of late sculptured pediment groups survive in museums, in fact rather more than from Greek or Roman temples, partly because the terracotta was not capable of "recycling" as [[marble]] was. The groups from [[Luna (Etruria)|Luni]] and [[Talamone]] (both now in [[Florence]]) are among the most impressive.<ref>Christofani; Banti, 31–32</ref>
Features shared by typical Etruscan and Roman temples, and contrasting with Greek ones, begin with a strongly frontal approach, with great emphasis on the front facade, less on the sides, and very little on the back. The podia are also usually higher, and can only be entered at a section of the front, just presenting a blank platform wall elsewhere. There may only be columns at the front portico.<ref>Christofani</ref> In Etruscan temples, more than Roman ones, the portico is deep, often representing, as Vitruvius recommends, half of the area under the roof, with multiple rows of columns.<ref>Christofani</ref>
At least in later temples, versions of Greek [[Aeolic order|Aeolic]], [[Ionic order|Ionic]] and [[Corinthian order|Corinthian]] capitals are found, as well as the main [[Tuscan order]], a simpler version of the [[Doric order|Doric]], but the attention to the full Greek detailing in the entablature that the Romans pursued seems to have been lacking. Fluted Tuscan/Doric columns can also be found, against Greek and later Roman conventions.<ref>Boethius, 49–54</ref>
Etruscan architecture shared with [[Ancient Egyptian architecture]] the use of large [[cavetto]] mouldings as a [[cornice]], though not on the same massive scale. The cavetto took the place of the Greek [[cymatium]] in many temples, often painted with vertical "tongue" patterns (as in the reconstructed Etruscan temple at [[Villa Giulia]], illustrated above), and combined with the distinctive "Etruscan round moulding", often painted with scales.<ref>Winter, 61-67; [[:File:Villa Giulia ricostruzione del tempio etrusco 01.JPG|Another view of the reconstructed Etruscan temple]] at [[Villa Giulia]]</ref>
===Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus=== [[File:TempleofCapitoliumRome.jpg|thumb|Speculative model of the first [[Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus]] in Rome]] The first building of the [[Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus]] on the [[Capitoline Hill]] was the oldest large temple in Rome, dedicated to the [[Capitoline Triad]] consisting of Jupiter and his companion deities, [[Juno (mythology)|Juno]] and [[Minerva]], and had a cathedral-like position in the official religion of Rome. Its first version was traditionally dedicated in 509 BC,<ref>[[Ab urbe condita (book)|Ab urbe condita]]'', 2.8</ref> but in 83 BC it was destroyed by fire, and the rebuilt Greek-style temple completed in 69 BC (there were to be two more fires and new buildings). For the first temple Etruscan specialists were brought in for various aspects of the building, including making and painting the extensive terracotta elements of the [[entablature]] or upper parts, such as [[antefix]]es.<ref>Stamper, 12–13</ref> But for the second building they were summoned from Greece.
The first version is the largest Etruscan temple recorded,<ref>Christofani; Boethius, 47</ref> and much larger than other Roman temples for centuries after. However, its size remains heavily disputed by specialists; based on an ancient visitor it has been claimed to have been almost {{convert|60|×|60|m|abbr=on}}, not far short of the largest Greek temples.<ref>Boethius, 47–48</ref> Whatever its size, its influence on other early Roman temples was significant and long-lasting.<ref>Stamper, 33 and all Chapters 1 and 2. Stamper is a leading protagonist of a smaller size, rejecting the larger size proposed by the late [[Einar Gjerstad]].</ref> Reconstructions usually show very wide eaves, and a wide colonnade stretching down the sides, though not round the back wall as it would have done in a Greek temple.<ref>Christofani</ref> A crude image on a coin of 78 BC shows only four columns, and a very busy roofline.<ref>[[:File:Tempel Jupiter Optimus.JPG|Denarius of 78 BC]]</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Etruskisk tempel.svg|Temple plan, following Vitruvius and the [[Portonaccio]] Minerva temple, with 3 doors File:Orvieto Tempio Etrusco Del Belvedere.JPG|Temple podium at [[Orvieto]]; above this level stone was probably not used File:Tempio di veio.JPG|Temple of Apollo, [[Portonaccio (Veio)|Veii]], with partial modern visualization File:St. Paul's Church, Covent Garden, London.jpg|[[St Paul's, Covent Garden]], London, 1630s, largely follows [[Vitruvius]]'s directions for a "Tuscan temple", but lacks external decoration and colour. File:Gorgoneion dal tempio di belvedere, orvieto, fine V sec. ac..JPG|[[Gorgon]] antefix, [[Orvieto]], end 5th century. Heads of both Silenus and gorgons were common subjects for antefixes. File:Antefissa a testa di sileno, 500-490 ac ca., da lanuvio (terme di diocleziano).JPG|Antefix with [[Silenus]], 500-490 BC File:MMA etruscan head0.jpg|Antefix File:Frontone A del grande tempio di luni con concilio degli dei, 175-150 ac. ca. 01.JPG|Remains of terracotta pediment group from [[Luna (Etruria)|Luna]] (paler areas reconstructed). </gallery>
==Monumental complexes== [[File:Terracotta architectural details Acquarossa.jpg|thumb|Frieze from [[Acquarossa, Italy|Acquarossa]] (Zone F)]] "Monumental complex" or building is a term used for a few large sets of buildings relatively recently uncovered by archaeology, the term reflecting a lack of certainty over their function. The two leading examples are "[[Poggio Civitate#The large Archaic building|the Archaic building]]" at [[Poggio Civitate]] and another at [[Acquarossa, Italy|Acquarossa]] (Zone F); both are 6th-century or earlier. Both have sets of buildings round a courtyard, which use stone, at least in the foundations, roof tiles, and elaborate decorations in architectural terracotta. Their size is exceptional for their early date. One obvious possible function is as palatial dwellings; another is as civic buildings, acting as places for assembly, and commemoration of aspects of the community. Only the stone foundations and ceramic fragments remain for excavations to discover.<ref>Meyers, 2–6</ref>
==Houses== It seems clear from the richer tombs that the Etruscan elite lived in fairly spacious comfort, but there is little evidence as to what their homes looked like, although some furniture is shown in tomb frescos. The rock-cut tomb chambers often form suites of "rooms", some quite large, which presumably resemble in part the [[atrium (architecture)|atrium]] homes of the better-off Etruscans.<ref>Boethius, 75–89; Banti, 27–28; Christofani</ref> Unlike several of the necropoli, Etruscan cities have generally been built over from the Romans onwards, and houses have left little trace. Where remains survive, there are tightly-packed tufa bases, with perhaps mud-brick above, but in some places the lower parts of tufa walls survive even in small houses. One complete set of foundations shows a house 7.9m by 3.9m (25 x 13 feet).<ref>Boethius, 75–77</ref> At large farms, mines, quarries and perhaps other sites employing many people (many or mostly slaves), workers lived in dormitories. [[File:Maquettes of houses from c 1000 BC.jpg|thumb|left|Selection of hut urns]]
A form of models of houses in pottery, and sometimes bronze, called "hut urns" gives us some indications. These were apparently used to hold cremated ashes, and are found in the preceding [[Villanovan culture]] and early Etruscan burials, especially in northern areas.<ref>Banti, 25; Boethius, 26–27</ref> The hut urns show a conventional model with a single interior space. They are usually round or slightly oval, often with prominent wooden beams laid in two rows on the sloping roof, which cross at the central ridge and project some way in "V"s into the air; these projections seem to have been sometimes carved or otherwise decorated. The urns always have a large square-ish door for access, sometimes two, and the outline of windows in the walls may be indicated by ridges or marks in the clay. There is very often a window and exit for smoke, above the door in the roof, and at the opposite end.<ref>Boethius, 26–27</ref>
Such houses were made of earth and organic materials, using mud brick and [[daub and wattle]].<ref>Banti, 25</ref> Stone [[hearth]]s and perhaps stone rings at the base are found. Even the well-off seem rarely to have lived in stone houses, and rock-cut tomb chambers often represent wooden ceilings in stone. The "Tomb of the Reliefs" at Banditaccia suggests that possessions such as tools and weapons were often hung from the walls for storage.<ref>Christofani</ref>
On the [[Palatine Hill]] in Rome, the [[Casa Romuli]] ("House of [[Romulus]]") was long preserved, and when necessary rebuilt as before. It was a hut made of wood posts and roof beams, [[wattle and daub]] walls and a [[thatch]]ed roof,<ref>Richardson, 74</ref> and possibly typical of ordinary Etruscan housing outside crowded city centres.<ref>Christofani</ref> The site cannot be identified with certainty, but at one candidate location circle of six [[post-hole]]s plus a central one have been found, cut into the tufa bedrock, with an ovoid 4.9m x 3.6m perimeter.
==Tombs and tumuli== [[File:Banditaccia Tomba Dei Capitelli.jpg|thumb|[[Banditaccia]] necropolis, Tomb of the Capitelli]] Rich Etruscans left elaborate tombs, mostly gathered in large [[necropoli]] some way outside their cities. These were generously filled with [[grave goods]],<ref>Banti, 20–21, 26, 28</ref> especially ceramics, which give us most of our understanding of Etruscan culture.<ref>Izzet, 16</ref> Typically, in the tufa regions of southern Etruria, the burial chamber was cut from solid rock below ground, which is relatively easy with this rock, but there was a structure above, often rather large. In other regions they are normally built up above ground.<ref>Banti, 21</ref> They were reused for further burials in the same family over several generations, and would often have become very crowded with sarchophagi and grave-goods, though the known survivals have now been emptied, either by looters or archaeologists.
Some tombs are stone buildings, often in rows, rather like small houses. Others are round [[tumuli]] with stone retaining walls, with steps down to rock-cut chambers below. Both types are found closely packed together in necropoli like [[Banditaccia]] and [[Monterozzi necropolis|Monterozzi]], the latter containing some 6,000 burials. Several different types of tombs have been identified, reflecting a development through time as well as differences in income. Some types clearly replicate aspects of the richer houses, with a number of connected chambers, columns with capitals, and rock-cut ceilings given beams.<ref>Christofani; Izzet, 16–17, cautions against transferring such details automatically</ref> Many tombs had [[fresco]] paintings, which does not seem to have been a Greek influence (though the style of the paintings are certainly based on Greek art), as the Greeks had ceased to use [[chamber tomb]]s well before the Etruscans started to paint theirs in about 600; the Egyptians had also ceased painting tombs by then.<ref>Banti, 29</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:TombaDadoBanditaccia.jpg|Tombs at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Banditaccia (Cerveteri)DSCF6681.jpg|Tombs at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Banditaccia (Cerveteri)DSCF6696.jpg|Tumulus at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Banditaccia (Cerveteri)DSCF6683.jpg|Maze of tumuli at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Necropoli crocifisso del tufo 2.jpg|View from above of a crowded necropolis at [[Orvieto]] File:Banditaccia (Cerveteri)DSCF6689.jpg|Tomb entry at [[Banditaccia]] necropolis File:Tombadeicaronti1.jpg|Painted false door; the "hammerhead" surround is a frequent motif File:Tomba dei Leopardi Tarquinia c.jpg|[[Tomb of the Leopards]], [[Tarquinia]] </gallery>
==Walls and fortifications== [[File:Orbetello12.jpg|thumb|Wall at Orbetello]] Etruscan cities, which often sat on hill-tops, became walled from about the 8th century, first in mud-brick, then often in stone. Even before the Romans began to swallow up Etruscan territory, Italy had frequent wars, and by the later period had [[Celts|Celtic]] enemies to the north, and an expanding Rome to the south.<ref>Boethius, 33–34</ref> There was an [[Agger (ancient Rome)|agger]] or rampart and a ''fossa'' or ditch in front of the wall. The towns had a number of gates where roads entered, which were sometimes given arched gateways. The best survivor of these is the 2nd-century Porta Marzia at [[Perugia]] (illustrated above) from the end of the period. Here, as in many cases, surviving work comes from the period just around the Roman takeover, but appears to represent Etruscan traditions. By the 4th century, [[Volterra]] had two walls, the second enclosing the whole city.<ref>Christofani; Boethius, 66–68</ref>
The stonework is often of fine quality, sometimes using regular rectangular blocks in a rough [[ashlar]], and sometimes "cyclopeian", using large polygonal blocks, partly shaped to fit each other, somewhat in the manner of the well-known [[Inca architecture|Inca masonry]], though not reaching that level of quality. Gaps are left, which are filled in with much smaller stones.<ref>Boëthius et al, 67–68</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="4"> File:Mura etrusche di fiesole 04 blocchi ciclopici.JPG|[[Fiesole]], town wall. Fairly regular blocks in courses File:Polygonal masonry wall of Rusellae.JPG|Polygonal masonry wall at [[Rusellae]] </gallery>
==Road network== [[File:Una via cava.JPG|thumb|240px|Sunken road or [[via cava]]]] Several important and unimportant [[Roman road]]s, such as the [[Via Cassia]], overlie Etruscan precursors, but there are sufficient Etruscan sites that were neglected after their conquest to allow an understanding of the considerable Etruscan road system. Roads did not just run between cities, but out into the countryside to allow agricultural produce to be easily brought in.<ref>Izzet, 193–195</ref> While not as heavily engineered as Roman roads, considerable efforts went into creating a road surface that on major routes could be as wide as 10.4 metres, on a 12 kilometre stretch connecting [[Cerveteri]] with its port [[Pyrgi]], made in the 5th century. This had a gravel surface, between tufo edging-blocks, and a central drainage channel.<ref>Izzet, 193</ref>
The [[Vie Cave]], narrow cuttings often running deeply through hills, are probably little changed since Etruscan times. As well as connecting sites, these may have had a defensive function in times of war. Their construction may have mainly resulted from the wearing through soft tufo bedrock by iron-rimmed wheels, creating deep ruts that required the road to be frequently recut to a smooth surface. Their dating can only be deduced by that of settlements they pass between, and objects from tombs beside them.<ref>Izzet, 193</ref> The 7th and 6th centuries show a move to replace earlier tracks only suitable for mules and pedestrians with wider and more engineered roads capable of taking wheeled vehicles, using gentler but longer routes through hilly country.<ref>Izzet, 194</ref>
Bridges were common, though fords more so where these would suffice. Presumably many were in timber, but some at least used stone underneath a timber roadway.<ref>Izzet, 195</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== {{commons category|Etruscan architecture}} *Ara della Regina, Gravisca and Giovanna Bagnasco Gianni, "Tarquinia, sacred areas and sanctuaries on the Civita plateau and on the coast: "monumental complex," in ''The Etruscan World'', edited by Jean MacIntosh Turfa, 2013, Routledge. {{ISBN|9780415673082}}. *Baglione, Maria Paola, "The Sanctuary at Pyrgi," in ''The Etruscan World'', edited by Jean MacIntosh Turfa, 2013, Routledge. {{ISBN|9780415673082}}. *Banti, Luisa, ''Etruscan Cities and Their Culture'', 1973, University of California Press, {{ISBN|0520019105}}, 9780520019102 *Bizzarri, Claudio, "Etruscan Town Planning and Related Structures," in ''The Etruscan World'', edited by Jean MacIntosh Turfa, 2013, Routledge. {{ISBN|9780415673082}}. *[[John Boardman (art historian)|Boardman, John]] ed., ''The Oxford History of Classical Art'', 1993, OUP, {{ISBN|0198143869}} *[[Axel Boëthius]], Roger Ling, Tom Rasmussen, ''Etruscan and Early Roman Architecture'', Yale University Press Pelican history of art, 1978, Yale University Press, {{ISBN|0300052901}}, 9780300052909, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=1nZswjfqROUC&printsec=frontcover google books] *Borrelli, Federica, Maria Cristina Targia, Stefano Peccatori, and Stefano Zuffi, ''The Etruscans: Art, Architecture, and History''. J. Paul Getty Museum, 2004. *Cristofani, Mauro, et al. "Etruscan; Architecture", [[Grove Art Online]],Oxford Art Online. Oxford University Press, accessed April 9, 2016, [http://www.oxfordartonline.com/subscriber/article/grove/art/T026914pg2 subscription required] *Edlund-Berry, Ingrid, "The architectural heritage of Etruria," in ''The Etruscan World'', edited by Jean MacIntosh Turfa, 2013, Routledge. {{ISBN|9780415673082}}. *Izzet, Vedia, ''The Archaeology of Etruscan Society'', 2007, Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|1107320917}}, 9781107320918, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=brPcLhGXez4C&pg=PA193 google books] *Meritt, Lucy Shoe, and Ingrid E. M. Edlund-Berry, ''Etruscan and Republican Roman Mouldings''. 2nd ed. University Museum, University of Pennsylvania in cooperation with the American Academy in Rome, 2000. *Meyers, Gretchen E., in Michael Thomas, Gretchen E. Meyers (eds.), ''Monumentality in Etruscan and Early Roman Architecture: Ideology and Innovation'', 2012, University of Texas Press, {{ISBN|0292749821}}, 9780292749825, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=wOezNYCGLc4C&printsec=frontcover google books] *Richardson, L. Jr., ''A New Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome'', 1992, JHU Press, {{ISBN|0801843006}}, 9780801843006, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=K_qjo30tjHAC&pg=PA74&lpg=PA74 google books] *Sprenger, Maja, Gilda Bartoloni, Max Hirmer, and Albert Hirmer. ''The Etruscans: Their History, Art, and Architecture''. H.N. Abrams, 1983. *Stamper, John, ''The architecture of Roman temples: the republic to the middle empire'', Cambridge University Press, 2005 *Taylor, Laurel, "Temple of Minerva and the sculpture of Apollo (Veii)", [https://www.khanacademy.org/humanities/ancient-art-civilizations/etruscan/a/temple-of-minerva-and-the-sculpture-of-apollo-veii Khan Academy essay] *Winter, Nancy A., "Monumentalization of the Etruscan Round Moulding in Sixth Century BCE Central Italy", in ''Monumentality in Etruscan and Early Roman Architecture: Ideology and Innovation'', edited by Michael Thomas, Gretchen E. Meyers, 2012, University of Texas Press, {{ISBN|0292749821}}, 9780292749825, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=wOezNYCGLc4C&pg=PA61 google books] *--, "The phenomenon of terracotta: architectural terracottas," in ''The Etruscan World'', edited by Jean MacIntosh Turfa, 2013, Routledge. {{ISBN|9780415673082}}.

revision.comment: Removal of promotional content. Addition of external sources.
revision.text:
{{advert|date=May 2017}}<!-- NOTE TO CREATOR: Don't take it personally, as this can call other users to help remove the promotional content themselves! ...Hopefully. --> '''Greenwich Dance''' is a [[dance]] organisation based in [[Greenwich]], [[London]]. Founded in 1993<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://londondance.com/articles/features/greenwich-dance-agency-the-first-10-years/|title=Greenwich Dance Agency - the first 10 years - LondonDance|work=LondonDance|access-date=2017-05-23|language=en}}</ref>, Greenwich Dance operates from The Borough Hall, the former [[Seat of local government|town hall]] of the [[Royal Borough of Greenwich]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://manchesterhistory.net/architecture/1930/greenwichTH.html|title=Greenwich Town Hall (former), London|website=manchesterhistory.net|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref>.
Greenwich Dance is a [[registered charity]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://beta.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-details/?regid=1029506&subid=0|title=Charity Details|website=beta.charitycommission.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref> and receives regular funding from [[Arts Council England]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/our-investment-2015-18/national-portfolio-organisations|title=National Portfolio Organisations {{!}} Arts Council England|website=www.artscouncil.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref> and Royal Borough of Greenwich.
Greenwich Dance is based in The Borough Hall, a historic Art Deco building in the heart of West Greenwich.
== Historic usage of The Borough Hall == The Borough Hall was designed by [[architect]] Clifford Culpin<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1213855|title=THE BOROUGH HALL AND MERIDIAN HOUSE (FORMER GREENWICH TOWN HALL), Greenwich - 1213855{{!}} Historic England|last=England|first=Historic|website=historicengland.org.uk|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref> and built in 1938-1939, and acted as the town hall for the [[Metropolitan Borough of Greenwich]] until a local authority merger in 1965<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2017-05-18|title=Royal Borough of Greenwich|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Royal_Borough_of_Greenwich&oldid=780923200|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}}</ref> resulted in the relocation of the Borough's town hall to Woolwich. The building was split into two in 1972-1974<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://manchesterhistory.net/architecture/1930/greenwichTH.html|title=Greenwich Town Hall (former), London|website=manchesterhistory.net|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref>, with [[Greenwich School of Management]] operating out of offices now named Meridian House.
The Borough Hall remained vacant until 1993 when Greenwich Dance began to operate from the venue. The building is [[Grade I and II* listed buildings in Greenwich|Grade-II* listed]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1213855|title=THE BOROUGH HALL AND MERIDIAN HOUSE (FORMER GREENWICH TOWN HALL), Greenwich - 1213855{{!}} Historic England|last=England|first=Historic|website=historicengland.org.uk|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref>.
The band [[Squeeze (band)|Squeeze]] performed their first gig at The Borough Hall in 1975.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.londonremembers.com/memorials/squeeze-debut-gig|title=Squeeze debut gig|website=London Remembers|language=en|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref> In 2010, [[PRS for Music]] erected a [[blue plaque]] on the side of the building to commemorate the event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://prsformusic.com/press/2010/prs-for-music-honours-squeezes-first-gig|title=PRS for Music honours Squeeze's first gig|website=prsformusic.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref>
== 1993 - present day == Since 1993, Greenwich Dance has operated the building on behalf of the owner, the Royal Borough of Greenwich. Nowadays the building hosts daily classes for professional dance artists, evening classes, events, performances and workshops.
The Borough Hall today contains three functional dance studios - The Borough Hall, The Minor Hall, and Studio 3<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rehearsalspacefinder.com/listing/greenwich-dance-the-borough-hall-royal-hill-se10-8re-the-borough-hall/|title=Greenwich Dance - The Borough Hall - Rehearsal Space Finder|work=Rehearsal Space Finder|access-date=2017-05-23|language=en-GB}}</ref>. The Borough Hall, the largest of the three, has a stage and an original 21m x 21m semi-sprung dance floor<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rehearsalspacefinder.com/listing/greenwich-dance-the-borough-hall-royal-hill-se10-8re-the-borough-hall/|title=Greenwich Dance - The Borough Hall - Rehearsal Space Finder|work=Rehearsal Space Finder|access-date=2017-05-23|language=en-GB}}</ref>, which was originally constructed in the 1930s as a social dance floor. As part of the organisation's support for professional dance artists, rehearsal spaces are hired out at reduced rates for independent dance artists.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://londondance.com/directory/dance-resources/studio-space-space-xchange/greenwich-dance/|title=Greenwich Dance - LondonDance|work=LondonDance|access-date=2017-09-14|language=en}}</ref>
The Borough Hall also houses the offices of other prominent local arts organisations, including [[Protein Dance]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.proteindance.co.uk/contact/|title=Protein Dance :: Contact|website=www.proteindance.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref> and [[Greenwich+Docklands International Festival]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.festival.org/about/contact/|title=Contact us - Greenwich+Docklands International Festival|website=www.festival.org|language=en|access-date=2017-05-23}}</ref>.
Each year, Greenwich Dance produce two festivals as part of the [[Royal Greenwich Festivals]] - Greenwich Dances<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.londonnewsonline.co.uk/24545/greenwichs-series-summer-festivals-kicks-literary-family-fun/|title=Greenwich's series of summer festivals kicks of with literary and family fun|last=Little|first=Mandy|date=2017-05-22|work=London News Online|access-date=2017-05-23|language=en-US}}</ref> and Greenwich World Cultural Festival<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.visitgreenwich.org.uk/events/greenwich-world-cultural-festival-2016/|title=Greenwich World Cultural Festival 2016|work=Visit Greenwich|access-date=2017-05-23|language=en-US}}</ref> (based at [[Eltham Palace]]). These are delivered on behalf of Royal Borough of Greenwich, the commissioners of Royal Greenwich Festivals.
== Role as Big Dance Hub == Acknowledging its role as the dance provider for South East London, in 2010 [[Big Dance UK|Big Dance]] commissioned Greenwich Dance <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bigdance.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2010/01/big-dance_press-release_20012010-2-Copy.pdf|title=Big Dance 2010 press release|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> to act as the Big Dance Hub for the London Boroughs of [[London Borough of Bexley|Bexley]], [[London Borough of Bromley|Bromley]], Greenwich and [[London Borough of Lewisham|Lewisham]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{coord missing|London}}

{{Infobox University | name = Harrington College of Design | established = 1931 | closed = 2015 | type = [[For-Profit School|For-profit]] | city = [[Chicago]] | state = [[Illinois]] | country = [[United States]] | address = 200 West [[Madison Street (Chicago)|Madison Street]] | coordinates = {{coord|41.88226|-87.63445|type:edu|display=inline,title}} | website = http://www.harrington.edu/ }}
'''Harrington College of Design''' (1931–2015) was a [[For-profit higher education in the United States|for-profit college]] in the [[Chicago Loop|Loop]] area of [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] that closed in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Harrington students settle in at Columbia after college closing|url=http://www.columbiachronicle.com/campus/article_6229d152-93a8-11e5-a66c-9784cd6abc0b.html|website=The Columbia Chronicle|accessdate=2017-08-31|date=2015-11-30}}</ref> It offered students programs leading to either a [[Master's degree|master's]], [[Bachelor's degree|bachelor's]], or [[associate's degree]] upon completion of the [[Interior Design]] Program, [[Digital Photography]] Program, or [[Communication Design]] Program. Each program was credentialed with multiple levels of accreditation. The school was owned by [[Career Education Corporation]].
==History== The school traced its history to 1931 when [[Frances Harrington]], a practicing interior designer, traveled to Chicago to provide a series of lectures for interior design professionals. She soon found a growing interest in the study of interior design and expanded her offerings by creating the Harrington Institute of Interior Design.
As Harrington Institute grew, Ms. Harrington began providing diplomas to her qualified day division students. When she retired in 1959, her former student Robert Marks assumed leadership of the school. Marks added many programs and degree options to the school's curriculum. Changes in programs, which are now under the guidance of the school's professional Advisory Board, are driven by input from the design industry's professional organizations.<ref name="OEDB">[http://oedb.org/campus/harrington-college-of-design ''Online Education Database''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118204857/http://oedb.org/campus/harrington-college-of-design |date=January 18, 2008 }}</ref>
In 2003, Harrington Institute changed its name to Harrington College of Design after being purchased by Career Education Corporation, and proceeded to expand the school's design-related programs of study. The school moved to its current location at 200 W. Madison Street and mandated an annual 20% enrollment increase, which they were able to sustain for a few years until the economy faltered then crashed in 2008. The campus at 200 W. Madison Street in Chicago closed at the end of the summer semester in August 2015.
==Academics== Harrington College of Design offered Bachelor's and associate degrees in [[Interior Design]], [[Digital Photography]] and [[Communication Design]]<ref name="educationcenteronline.org">[http://www.educationcenteronline.org/AllSchools/Harrington-College-of-Design.html Harrington College of Design - Education Center Online<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100502053923/http://www.educationcenteronline.org/AllSchools/Harrington-College-of-Design.html |date=May 2, 2010 }}</ref>
===Accreditation=== Harrington was regionally accredited by [[The Higher Learning Commission]] of the [[North Central Association of Colleges and Schools]] from January 01 2010 until June 30 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ope.ed.gov/accreditation/InstAccrDetails.aspx?756e697469643d3131333039362663616d70757349643d30267264743d372f32302f323031372031323a33313a313320504d|title=U.S. Department of Education Database of Accredited Postsecondary Institutions and Programs|website=ope.ed.gov|accessdate=10 June 2018}}</ref> and nationally accredited by the [[Accrediting Council for Independent Colleges and Schools]] to award associate, bachelor's, and master's degrees. Since the school has both [[regional accreditation]] and [[national accreditation]], most schools will accept their credits in transfer and recognize their degrees for entry into graduate programs.<ref name="demand">[http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2005/10/19/transfer ''Demanding Credit'', Inside Higher Education website, dated October 19, 2005 by Scott Jaschik] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305192541/http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2005/10/19/transfer |date=March 5, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="tussle">[http://insidehighered.com/news/2007/02/26/transfer ''Tussling Over Transfer of Credit'', Inside Higher Education website, February 26, 2007 by Doug Lederman] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115210406/http://insidehighered.com/news/2007/02/26/transfer |date=January 15, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="yahoo">[http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/education/courses/distancelearn-09.html ''What is the Difference Between Regional and National Accreditation'', Yahoo! Education website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080119100801/http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/education/courses/distancelearn-09.html |date=January 19, 2008 }}</ref><ref name="usaed">[http://www.useducation.com.pk/stpages/typesofaccreditation.html ''Types of Accreditation'', Education USA website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080424074806/http://www.useducation.com.pk/stpages/typesofaccreditation.html |date=April 24, 2008 }}</ref>
Additionally, Harrington was recognized as a private college by the [[Illinois Board of Higher Education]] (IBHE) and was authorized by the IBHE to confer associate, baccalaureate and master's degrees. The Interior Design Program leading to the bachelor of fine arts degree was accredited by the Council for Interior Design Accreditation (formerly FIDER). The college was also accredited by the Council for Interior Design Accreditation.
Harrington College of Design’s Bachelor of Fine Arts Degree in Interior Design was accredited by the [[Council for Interior Design Accreditation]] (formerly FIDER). The Associate of Applied Science Degree in Interior Design was not accredited by the Council for Interior Design Accreditation.<ref name="accreditation">[http://www.accredit-id.org/accredhistory.html ''Council for Interior Design Accreditation''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071212151703/http://www.accredit-id.org/accredhistory.html |date=December 12, 2007 }}</ref>
==Campus== Harrington had a six-story, {{convert|82000|sqft|m2}} vertical campus located in the [[Chicago Loop]]. Three floors of the campus served as a display space, designed to hold a mix of classrooms, galleries and offices. Harrington also had an extensive library that contains updated digital research for students.
==Organizations== Harrington College of Design belonged to several organizations:
*'''American Society of Interior Design (ASID) Student Chapter''' — Helps students gain connections with professionals in the design industry.<ref name="ASID">[https://www.asid.org/studentcenter/Student+Chapter+Schools+by+State.htm ''ASID'', student chapter schools] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115081207/https://www.asid.org/studentcenter/Student+Chapter+Schools+by+State.htm |date=January 15, 2008 }}</ref> *'''[[International Interior Design Association]] (IIDA)''' — A professional networking and education association that serves the interior design community. *'''American Society of Media Photographers (ASMP)''' — The leading association of photographers supporting photographers.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.harrington.edu/ Official website]
{{Career Education Corporation}} {{colleges and universities in metropolitan Chicago}}

{{Italic title}} '''''In Mourning and in Rage''''' was a work of [[performance art]] and activism by [[Suzanne Lacy]] and [[Leslie Labowitz-Starus|Leslie Labowitz]]. The performance took place in [[Los Angeles]], California in 1977 as a response to the rapes and murders covered by the media in the "[[Hillside Strangler]]" case.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Labowitz-Starus|first=Leslie|last2=Lacy|first2=Suzanne|date=1978-01-01|title="In Mourning and in Rage ..."|jstor=3345993|journal=Frontiers: A Journal of Women Studies|volume=3|issue=1|pages=52–55|doi=10.2307/3345993}}</ref>"As if the horror of these crimes wasn't enough, the press coverage of the events sensationalized the sexual nature of the crimes. For feminist activists in Los Angeles involved in the movement to end violence against women, this analysis was unacceptable."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Moravec|first1=Michelle|title=In Mourning and In Rage|url=http://historyinthecity.blogspot.com/2011/09/in-mourning-and-in-rage.html|website=History of the City|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref>
A continuation of ''Three Weeks in May,'' Lacy and Labowitz designed ''In Mourning and in Rage'' as a personal response to the sensationalized media coverage of violence against women as well as an expression of grief and rage towards the loss of life. The performance was a collaboration between Lacy, Labowitz, Bia Lowe, [[Holly Near]], City Councilwoman Pat Russel, the [[Woman's Building]], Women Against Violence Against Women, and Los Angeles Commission on Assaults Against Women. The event was staged for mass media coverage at the [[Los Angeles City Hall]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.suzannelacy.com/in-mourning-and-in-rage-1977/|title=In Mourning and In Rage (1977)|website=SUZANNE LACY|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/women-art-and-society/oclc/930389708&referer=brief_results|title=Women, art, and society|last=Chadwick|first=Whitney|date=2012-01-01|publisher=Thames & Hudson|isbn=9780500204054|location=London|language=English}}</ref>
The performance consisted of a large funeral motorcade of black-clad women lead by a hearse from the [[Woman's Building]] to the Los Angeles City Hall. Once there, nine seven-feet-tall women draped in black emerged from the hearse along with a women dressed in red. The mourners then climbed the steps of city hall where each of the nine women gave a statement into a microphone expressing their solidarity with the murdered women, emphasized by a chorus of "In memory of our sisters, we fight back!" from the rest of the motorcade.<ref name=":0" /> By making this performance public as well as highly crafted for media coverage, Lacy and Labowitz looked to highlight not only the deaths of the ten women killed by the [[Hillside Strangler]], but the significantly larger population of women victims whose stories went uncovered by mainstream media.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/801307168|title=Pacific standard time : Los Angeles art 1945-1980|last=Rebecca.|first=Peabody,|last2=Calif.)|first2=J. Paul Getty Museum (Los Angeles,|date=2011-01-01|publisher=The Getty Research Institute and the J. Paul Getty Museum|year=|isbn=1606060724|location=|pages=258–259|oclc=801307168}}</ref>
The piece concluded with direct statements to the press explaining the rationale for the piece as well as a speech demanding resources for women's self defense. Singer-songwriter [[Holly Near]] performed her song "Fight Back"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Near|first1=Holly|title=Fight Back|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sBE4Au5myko|website=Youtube|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> which was written specifically for this event.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Irish|first1=Sharon|title=Suzanne Lacy: Spaces Between|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s0fCKMCOdO0C&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72&dq=fight+back+holly+near+composed+lacy&source=bl&ots=Q4DGhJL3eI&sig=kM9wgfqVxJWggucbF-__So5cXqo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiHro--i_zSAhXmsFQKHdNmDVsQ6AEIMDAD#v=onepage&q=fight%20back%20holly%20near%20composed%20lacy&f=false|website=Google Books|publisher=Univ Of Minnesota Press (February 12, 2010)|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
== Legacy == ''In Mourning and in Rage'' was highly covered by the press and resulted in increased support from Los Angeles City Council members and a pledge from the Rape Hotline Alliance to provide self defense classes.<ref name=":1" />
To further the conversation about social action and art, Lacy and Labowitz produced a video documenting ''In Mourning and in Rage'' as well as a pamphlet entitled ''What is Social Art?.''
== See also == * ''[[Three Weeks in May]]'' * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=idK02tPdYV0&t=21s In Mourning and In Rage Video Documentation]
