{{Redirect|Keep Calm|the novel|Keep Calm (novel)}} {{about|the poster|the Stereophonics album|Keep Calm and Carry On (album)|the TV series episode|Keep Calm and Carry On (Supernatural)}} {{italic title}} {{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}}
<!-- This has been replaced by the SVG poster before. Please don't replace this without a discussion on the "talk" page. --> [[File:Keep-calm-and-carry-on-scan.jpg|thumb|The original 1939 ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' poster]]
'''''Keep Calm and Carry On''''' is a [[motivational poster]] produced by the [[Government of the United Kingdom|British government]] in 1939 in preparation for [[World War II]]. The poster was intended to raise the [[morale]] of the British public, threatened with widely predicted mass air attacks on major cities.<ref>{{cite book |first=Richard |last=Slocombe |title=British Posters of the Second World War |location=London |publisher=Imperial War Museum |year=2010 |isbn=9781904897927 |page=6 }}</ref><ref name="PhD">{{cite web |url=http://ww2poster.co.uk/2009/04/1939-3-posters/ |title=1939: The Three Posters (PhD Extract) |first=Rebecca, PhD |last=Lewis |work=Keep Calm and Carry on and other Second World War Posters: British Home Front Propaganda Posters of the Second World War |date=5 April 2009}}</ref> Although 2.45 million copies were printed, and although [[the Blitz]] did in fact take place, the poster was hardly ever publicly displayed and was little known until a copy was rediscovered in 2000 at [[Barter Books]], a bookshop in [[Alnwick]]. It has since been re-issued by a number of private companies, and has been used as the decorative theme for a range of products.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/7869458.stm|title=The Greatest Motivational Poster Ever?|work=''BBC News''|date= 4 February 2009|first=Stuart|last=Hughes}}</ref>
Evocative of the Victorian belief in British stoicism – the "[[stiff upper lip]]", self-discipline, fortitude, and remaining calm in adversity – the poster has become recognised around the world.<ref>{{cite news|title=Keep calm and carry on … bidding for rare poster|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/jun/25/wartime-poster-secret-auction|work=The Guardian|date=2 October 2016}}</ref> It was thought that only two original copies survived until a collection of approximately 15 was brought in to the ''[[Antiques Roadshow]]'' in 2012 by the daughter of an ex-[[Royal Observer Corps]] member.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2105518/Keep-calm-carry-Only-surviving-stash-original-iconic-poster-appears-Antiques-Roadshow.html|accessdate=13 May 2012|location=London|work=Daily Mail|first=Chris|last=Slack|title=Keep Calm and Carry On... to the bank: Original wartime poster shows up on Antiques Roadshow|date=23 February 2012}}</ref> A few further examples have come to light since.<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 63.</ref>
==History==
===Design and production=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = | header_background = pink | footer = | footer_align = | footer_background = pink | width = 129
| image1 = Freedomisinperilposter.jpg | width1 = 130 | alt1 = | caption1 = "Freedom Is in Peril" (reconstruction)
| image2 = Your Courage, Your Cheerfulness, Your Resolution Will Bring Us Victory.svg | width2 = 130 | alt2 = | caption2 = "Your Courage" (reconstruction) }} The ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' poster was designed by the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] during the period of 27 June to 6 July 1939.<ref name="irving">{{cite web |url= https://history.blog.gov.uk/2014/06/27/keep-calm-and-carry-on-the-compromise-behind-the-slogan/ |title=Keep Calm and Carry On – The Compromise Behind the Slogan |first=Henry |last=Irving |publisher= History of Government Blog |date= 27 June 2014 |accessdate= 27 June 2014}}</ref> It was produced as part of a series of three "Home Publicity" posters (the others read "<u>Your</u> ''Courage,'' <u>Your</u> ''Cheerfulness,'' <u>Your</u> ''Resolution Will Bring Us Victory''" and "''Freedom Is in Peril / Defend It With All Your Might''"). Each poster showed the slogan under a representation of a "[[Tudor Crown (heraldry)|Tudor Crown]]" (a symbol of the state). They were intended to be distributed to strengthen morale in the event of a wartime disaster, such as mass bombing of major cities using high explosives and poison gas, which was widely expected within hours of an outbreak of war.<ref name="PhD"/>
A career civil servant named A. P. Waterfield came up with "Your Courage" as "a rallying war-cry that will bring out the best in everyone of us and put us in an offensive mood at once".<ref name="PhD"/><ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 45–6.</ref> Others involved in the planning of the early posters included: [[John Hilton (industrial relations)|John Hilton]], [[Montague Burton Professor of Industrial Relations|Professor of Industrial Relations]] at [[Cambridge University]], responsible overall as Director of Home Publicity; William Surrey Dane, managing director at [[Odhams Press]]; [[Gervas Huxley]], former head of publicity for the [[Empire Marketing Board]]; William Codling, controller of [[HMSO]]; [[Harold Nicolson]], MP; W. G. V. Vaughan, who became Director of the General Production Division (GPD); H. V. Rhodes, who later wrote an occasional paper on setting up a new government department; [[Ivison Macadam]]; "Mr Cruthley"; and "Mr Francis". [[Ernest Wallcousins]] was the artist tasked with creating the poster designs.<ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 42, 44, 47.</ref>
Detailed planning for the posters had started in April 1939 and the eventual designs were prepared after meetings between officials from the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] and [[HM Treasury]] on 26 June 1939 and between officials from the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] and [[HMSO]] on 27 June 1939.<ref name="irving"/> Roughs of the poster were completed on 6 July 1939, and the final designs were agreed by the Home Secretary [[Samuel Hoare, 1st Viscount Templewood]] on 4 August 1939. Printing began on 23 August 1939, the day that Nazi Germany and the USSR signed the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]], and the posters were ready to be placed up within 24 hours of the outbreak of war.<ref name="irving"/>
The posters were produced in 11 different sizes, ranging from {{convert|15|xx|10|in|cm}} up to large 48-sheet versions.<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 47.</ref> The background colour was either red or blue.<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 53.</ref> The lettering was probably hand-drawn by Wallcousins:<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kominek|first1=Lex|title=Keep Calm and Carry On – WWII Posters |url=http://www.typophile.com/node/39466#comment-242245|publisher=Typophile|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref><ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 44, 47.</ref> it is similar, but not identical, to [[humanist sans-serif typeface]]s such as [[Gill Sans]] and [[Johnston (typeface)|Johnston]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Keep Calm and Carry On: Fonts|url=http://www.k-type.com/keep-calm-carry-on/|publisher=K-Type|accessdate=28 September 2014}} For distinctive features, see for example the terminals of the "C".</ref>
Almost 2,500,000 copies of ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' were printed between 23 August and 3 September 1939 but the poster was not sanctioned for immediate public display.<ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 49–50.</ref> It was instead decided that copies should remain in "cold storage" for use after serious air raids (with resources transferred to ''Your Courage'' and ''Freedom is in Peril''). Copies of ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' were retained until April 1940, but stocks were then pulped as part of the wider [[Paper Salvage 1939–50|Paper Salvage]] campaign.<ref name="irving"/> A very few copies do appear to have been displayed, but such instances were rare and unauthorised: an October 1940 edition of the ''[[The Yorkshire Post|Yorkshire Post]]'' reports the poster hung in a shop in [[Leeds]];<ref>{{cite news |date=22 October 1940 |title=Ban on Silk Stockings: Should They Have Been Rationed? |newspaper=[[The Yorkshire Post|Yorkshire Post and Leeds Mercury]] |page=4 |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/search/results?basicsearch=%22few%20had%20eyes%20for%20the%20poster%22 |accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> while a photograph discovered in 2016 shows it on the wall of a government laboratory in [[Bedfordshire]].<ref>{{cite news |first1=Patrick |last1=Sawer |first2=Paul |last2=Hooley |title=Wartime rebels who broke the ban by displaying keep calm and carry on poster |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=30 October 2016 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/10/29/wartime-rebels-who-broke-the-ban-by-displaying-keep-calm-and-car/ |accessdate=5 October 2018 }}</ref>
The remainder of the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] publicity campaign was cancelled in October 1939 following criticism of its cost and impact. Many people claimed not to have seen the posters; while those who did see them regarded them as patronising and divisive.<ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 52–57.</ref><ref>{{cite news|authorlink=Nigel Rees |last=Rees |first=Nigel |date=20 July 2011|title=Cheer up, the worst is yet to come|work=[[Today programme]]|publisher=[[BBC Radio 4]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9543000/9543352.stm}}</ref> Design historian Susannah Walker regards the campaign as "a resounding failure" and reflective of a misjudgement by upper-class civil servants of the mood of the people.<ref>Walker 2012, pp.6–7.</ref>
===Later developments=== In late May and early June 1941, 14,000,000 copies of a leaflet entitled "Beating the Invader" were distributed with a message from Prime Minister [[Winston Churchill]]. The leaflet begins "If invasion comes..." and exhorts the populace to "Stand Firm" and "Carry On". The two phrases do not appear in one sentence, as they applied to different segments of the population depending on their circumstances, with those civilians finding themselves in areas of fighting ordered to stand firm (i.e., stay put) and those not in areas of fighting ordered to carry on (i.e., continue vital war work). Each mandate is identified as a "great order and duty" should invasion come. The leaflet then lists 14 questions and answers on practical measures to be taken.<ref>{{cite news|title=If Invasion Comes. Mr. Churchill's Orders. "Stand Firm and Carry On."|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47326422|work=The West Australian|date=26 May 1941|location=Perth, WA, Australia|page=6}}</ref>
===Rediscovery and commercialisation=== [[File:Keep Calm And Carry On - Original poster - Barter Books - 17-Oct-2011.jpg|thumb|left|upright|The poster discovered at Barter Books]] [[File:Keep Calm merchandise.jpg|thumb|right|2013 shop display of "Keep Calm" merchandise, including the original slogan and variants such as "Keep Calm and Drink Tea".]] In 2000, Stuart Manley, co-owner with his wife Mary of [[Barter Books]] Ltd. in [[Alnwick]], Northumberland, was sorting through a box of used books bought at auction when he uncovered one of the original "Keep Calm and Carry On" posters. The couple framed it and hung it up by the cash register; it attracted so much interest that Manley began to produce and sell copies.<ref name="Rediscovery">{{cite web |url=http://www.keepcalmhome.com/about.htm |title=About Keep Calm and Carry On}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/first-person-i-am-the-keep-calm-and-carry-on-man-1672398.html |first=Stuart |last=Manley |title=First person: 'I am the Keep Calm and Carry On man' |newspaper=The Independent |date=25 April 2009 |accessdate=20 August 2018 }}</ref> In late 2005, ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' journalist Susie Steiner featured the replica posters as a Christmas gift suggestion, raising their profile still further.<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 64.</ref> Other companies followed the Manleys' example, and the design rapidly began to be used as the theme for a wide range of products.<ref name=feud>{{cite news |title=Keep Calm and carry on ... into a feud |url= http://www.smh.com.au/world/keep-calm-and-carry-on--into-a-feud-20130503-2ix55.html |accessdate= 4 May 2013 |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date= 4 May 2013}}</ref> Mary Manley later commented, "I didn't want it trivialised; but of course now it's been trivialised beyond belief."<ref name=feud/>
In early 2012, Barter Books debuted an informational short film, ''The Story of Keep Calm and Carry On'', providing visual insight into the modernisation and commercialisation of the design and the phrase.<ref>{{YouTube|id=FrHkKXFRbCI|title=The Story of Keep Calm and Carry On}}</ref>
The poster has become an evocation of British stoicism: the "[[stiff upper lip]]", self-discipline, fortitude and remaining calm in adversity. Susannah Walker comments that it is now seen "not only as a distillation of a crucial moment in Britishness, but also as an inspiring message from the past to the present in a time of crisis".<ref name="Walker"/> She goes on to point out, however, that such an interpretation overlooks the circumstances of its production, and the relative failure of the campaign of which it formed a part.<ref name="Walker">Walker 2012, p. 45.</ref>
=== Trademark claims === {{update|section|date=March 2015}} In August 2011, it was reported that a UK-based company called Keep Calm and Carry On Ltd<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.keepcalmandcarryon.com |title=Keep Calm and Carry On Ltd |publisher=Keepcalmandcarryon.com |accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref> (managed by entrepreneur Mark Coop) had registered the slogan as a [[community trade mark]] in the EU, CTM No: 009455619, and in the United States, No. 4066622,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theawl.com/2011/10/keep-calm-and-carry-on-trademark-fight|title=The Vicious Trademark Battle Over 'Keep Calm and Carry On'|date=5 October 2011|publisher=[[The Awl]] |first=Maria |last=Bustillos |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301012125/http://www.theawl.com/2011/10/keep-calm-and-carry-on-trademark-fight |archivedate=1 March 2016}}</ref><ref name="Phillips">{{cite web |last=Phillips |first=Jeremy |title=Monday miscellany |date=22 August 2011|url = http://ipkitten.blogspot.com/2011/08/monday-miscellany_22.html|publisher=IPKitten blog}}</ref> after failing to obtain its registration as a trademark in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Rayner">{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/8785585/Battle-rages-over-Keep-Calm-and-Carry-On-souvenirs.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Gordon |last=Rayner |title=Battle rages over 'Keep Calm and Carry On' souvenirs | date=24 September 2011}}</ref><ref name="lew74">Lewis 2017, pp. 74–5.</ref> The company issued a take-down request against a seller of ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' products.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15014748|title=Battle over trademark of 'keep calm' phrase|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=22 September 2010|accessdate=22 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Keep calm and carry on items removed from my ebay account |publisher=justanswer.com |date=August 2011 |url=http://www.justanswer.com/uk-law/5e2l0-keep-calm-carry-items-removed.html}}</ref> The company's right to claim the trademark was questioned by, among others, the Manleys of Barter Books, as the slogan had been widely used before registration and was not recognisable as indicating trade origin.<ref name="Phillips"/><ref name="lew74"/> An application was submitted by British intellectual property advisor and UK trademarking service Trade Mark Direct to cancel the registration on the grounds that the words were too widely used for one person to own the exclusive rights,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freelanceuk.com/news/3912.shtml|title=IP group aims to reclaim 'Keep Calm & Carry On'|publisher=freelanceuk.com}}</ref> but the request for cancellation was rejected and the trade mark is still protected in all EU countries.<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 75.</ref> The company subsequently tried to register the slogan as its trademark in both the United States<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tarr.uspto.gov/servlet/tarr?regser=serial&entry=85297485 |title=Serial Number: 85297485 Keep Calm and Carry On USA Trademark|work=Official Gazette|date=20 September 2011|publisher=[[USPTO]]}}</ref> and Canada.<ref name="Rayner"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ic.gc.ca/app/opic-cipo/trdmrks/srch/vwTrdmrk.do;jsessionid=0001K46wR_Bu__TfKBulXGEhGen:-14J2QPI?lang=eng&status=&fileNumber=1524133&extension=0&startingDocumentIndexOnPage=1 |title= Canadian Trade-mark Data |publisher= IC.GC.CA |date= 13 October 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Stay Alive and Avoid Zombies.png|thumb|left|upright|A 2009 parody of the poster]] [[File:Cyber Candy Birmingham after riots.jpg|thumb|right|upright|"Keep Calm and Candy On" painted on boards covering smashed windows of a [[Confectionery store|sweet shop]] in Birmingham during the [[2011 England riots]]]]
==Imitations== As the popularity of the poster in various media has grown, innumerable parodies, imitations and co-optations have also appeared, making it a notable [[Internet meme|meme]]. Messages range from the cute to the overtly political, typically with references to other aspects of popular culture raging from [[Land Rover]] and [[Disney]] to [[Star Wars]] and [[Thomas the Tank Engine]]. Examples have included "Now Panic and Freak Out" (with an upside-down crown), "Get Excited and Make Things" (with a crown incorporating [[wrench|spanners]]), "Keep Calm and Have a Cupcake" (with a [[cupcake]] icon), "Don't Panic and Fake a British Accent", "Keep Spending and Carry On Shopping",<ref name="NYT mag story">{{cite news |last=Walker|first=Rob|authorlink=Rob Walker (journalist) |title=Remixed Messages |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/magazine/05FOB-consumed-t.html?_r=2&ref=magazine |work=[[The New York Times Magazine]] |date=5 July 2009 |accessdate= 21 March 2012}}</ref> "Keep Calm and Don't Sneeze" during the [[2009 flu pandemic in the United Kingdom|2009 swine flu pandemic]],<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 66.</ref> "Keep Calm and Call Batman" (with the Batman logo),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://batman-news.com/2013/07/09/new-batman-easter-egg-from-man-of-steel-revealed|title=New Batman Easter egg from 'Man of Steel' revealed|author=Chris Begley |date=9 July 2013 |website=batman-news.com |access-date=13 February 2017}}</ref> and "Keep Calm and Switch to Linux" (with [[Tux (mascot)|Tux]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Keep calm and switch to Linux |url=http://th03.deviantart.net/fs71/PRE/i/2011/265/2/a/keep_calm_and_switch_to_linux_by_devianteles-d4am5ur.png}}</ref> In March–April 2012, the British pop-rock band [[McFly]] undertook a theatre tour entitled "[[The Keep Calm & Play Louder Tour|The Keep Calm and Play Louder Tour]]", promoted with a poster closely based on that of 1939. In late 2012 and early 2013, the "Save Lewisham Hospital" campaign (a protest against proposed cuts in services at [[University Hospital Lewisham]]) made widespread use of a poster with the slogan "Don't Keep Calm Get Angry and Save Lewisham A&E".<ref>{{cite news |last=Little |first=Mandy |title=Protestors show unity |newspaper=South London Press |location=London |date=21 December 2012 |accessdate=27 January 2013 |url=http://www.southlondon-today.co.uk/News.cfm?id=44283&headline=Protestors%20show%20unity |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928023806/http://www.southlondon-today.co.uk/News.cfm?id=44283&headline=Protestors%20show%20unity |archive-date=28 September 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |year=2013 |publisher=Save Lewisham Hospital campaign |url=http://www.savelewishamhospital.com/ |title=Save Lewisham Hospital! |accessdate=27 January 2013}}</ref> The efforts of [[Naheed Nenshi]], mayor of [[Calgary]], Alberta, Canada, to encourage and motivate his citizens in the wake of the [[2013 Alberta floods]] made him the subject of parody "Keep Calm and Nenshi On" fundraising T-shirts.<ref>{{cite news|author=Dean Bennett |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/mayor-nenshi-has-captured-calgarys-heart-but-the-worst-at-least-politically-is-yet-to-come/article12884159/ |title=Mayor Nenshi has captured Calgary's heart, but the worst, at least politically, is yet to come |work=The Globe and Mail |date=28 June 2013 |accessdate=24 February 2014 |location=Toronto}}</ref>

All books in the various [[Tom Swift]] book series.
==Books of the original ''Tom Swift'' series<ref name="cooper1"> {{cite web | url=http://www.tomswift.info/homepage/oldindex.html | title=The Complete Tom Swift Sr. Home Page|accessdate=2 April 2011}}</ref>== #''[[Tom Swift and His Motor Cycle]]; or, Fun and Adventure on the Road'', 1910 #''[[Tom Swift and His Motor Boat]]; or, The Rivals of Lake Carlopa'', 1910 #''[[Tom Swift and His Airship]]; or, The Stirring Cruise of the Red Cloud'', 1910 #''[[Tom Swift and His Submarine Boat]]; or, Under the Ocean for Sunken Treasure'', 1910 #''[[Tom Swift and His Electric Runabout]]; or, The Speediest Car on the Road'', 1910 #''[[Tom Swift and His Wireless Message]]; or, The Castaways of Earthquake Island'', 1911 #''[[Tom Swift Among the Diamond Makers]]; or, The Secret of Phantom Mountain'', 1911 #''[[Tom Swift in the Caves of Ice]]; or, The Wreck of the Airship'', 1911 #''[[Tom Swift and His Sky Racer]]; or, The Quickest Flight on Record'', 1911 #''[[Tom Swift and His Electric Rifle]]; or, Daring Adventures on Elephant Island'', 1911 #''[[Tom Swift in the City of Gold]]; or, Marvelous Adventures Underground'', 1912 #''[[Tom Swift and His Air Glider]]; or, Seeking the Platinum Treasure'', 1912 #''[[Tom Swift in Captivity]]; or, A Daring Escape by Airship'', 1912 #''[[Tom Swift and His Wizard Camera]]; or, Thrilling Adventures While Taking Moving Pictures'', 1912 #''[[Tom Swift and His Great Searchlight]]; or, On the Border for Uncle Sam'', 1912 #''[[Tom Swift and His Giant Cannon]]; or, The Longest Shots on Record'', 1913 #''[[Tom Swift and His Photo Telephone]]; or, The Picture That Saved a Fortune'', 1914 #''[[Tom Swift and His Aerial Warship]]; or, The Naval Terror of the Seas'', 1915 #''[[Tom Swift and His Big Tunnel]]; or, The Hidden City of the Andes'', 1916 #''[[Tom Swift in the Land of Wonders]]; or, The Underground Search for the Idol of Gold'', 1917 #''[[Tom Swift and His War Tank]]; or, Doing His Bit for Uncle Sam'', 1918 #''[[Tom Swift and His Air Scout]]; or, Uncle Sam's Mastery of the Sky'', 1919 #''[[Tom Swift and His Undersea Search]]; or, The Treasure on the Floor of the Atlantic'', 1920 #''[[Tom Swift Among the Fire Fighters]]; or, Battling with Flames in the Air'', 1921 #''[[Tom Swift and His Electric Locomotive]]; or, Two Miles a Minute on the Rails'', 1922 #''Tom Swift and His Flying Boat; or, Castaways of the Giant Iceberg'', 1923 #''Tom Swift and His Great Oil Gusher; or, The Treasure of Goby Farm'', 1924 #''Tom Swift and His Chest of Secrets; or, Tracing the Stolen Inventions'', 1925 #''Tom Swift and His Airline Express; or, From Ocean to Ocean by Daylight'', 1926 #''Tom Swift Circling the Globe; or, The Daring Cruise of the Air Monarch'', 1927 #''Tom Swift and His Talking Pictures; or, The Greatest Invention on Record'', 1928 #''Tom Swift and His House on Wheels; or, A Trip around the Mountain of Mystery'', 1929 #''Tom Swift and His Big Dirigible; or, Adventures Over the Forest of Fire'', 1930 #''Tom Swift and His Sky Train; or, Overland Through the Clouds'', 1931 #''Tom Swift and His Giant Magnet; or, Bringing Up the Lost Submarine'', 1932 #''Tom Swift and His Television Detector; or, Trailing the Secret Plotters'', 1933 #''Tom Swift and His Ocean Airport; or, Foiling the Haargolanders'', 1934 #''Tom Swift and His Planet Stone; or, Discovering the Secret of Another World'', 1935 #''Tom Swift and His Giant Telescope'', 1939 (Better Little Book) — [http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/21188 e-text at [[Project Gutenberg]]] #''Tom Swift and His Magnetic Silencer'', 1941 (Better Little Book)
The first 25 and the 39th Tom Swift Sr. books are in the [[public domain]] all around the world and are available as downloadable texts from [[Project Gutenberg]]. However, in Canada, due to its life plus 50 years policy, and because [[Howard R. Garis]] and Thomas Moyston Mitchell died in 1962, on January 1, 2013 volumes 1 to 35 (written by Garis) and 39-40 (written by Mitchell) entered into the Canadian Public Domain. (Canadian Copyright Act, Sections 6.1 and 6.2) This applies to other countries as well that have a life plus 50 policy. Volumes 36 to 38, which were written by [[Harriet Adams|Harriet Stratemeyer-Adams]], will enter the Canadian Public Domain on January 1, 2033.
==Books of the second series by Victor Appleton II (Tom Swift Jr.)<ref name="cooper2">{{cite web|url=http://www.tomswift.info/homepage/index.html|title = The Complete Tom Swift Jr. Home Page|accessdate=28 April 2011}}</ref>== #''Tom Swift and his Flying Lab'' 1954 (by William Dougherty) #''Tom Swift and His Jetmarine'' 1954 (by John Almquist) #''Tom Swift and His Rocket Ship'' 1954 (by John Almquist) #''Tom Swift and His Giant Robot'' 1954 (by Richard Sklar) #''Tom Swift and His Atomic Earth Blaster'' 1954 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Outpost in Space'' 1955 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Diving Seacopter'' 1956 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift in the Caves of Nuclear Fire'' 1956 (by Thomas Mulvey) #''Tom Swift on the Phantom Satellite'' 1956 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Ultrasonic Cycloplane'' 1957 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Deep-Sea Hydrodome'' 1958 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift in the Race to the Moon'' 1958 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Space Solartron'' 1958 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Electronic Retroscope'' 1959 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Spectromarine Selector'' 1960 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and the Cosmic Astronauts'' 1960 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and the Visitor from Planet X'' 1961 (by James Duncan Lawrence) — [http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/17985 e-text at [[Project Gutenberg]]] #''Tom Swift and the Electronic Hydrolung'' 1961 (by James Duncan Lawrence) — [http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/19258 e-text at [[Project Gutenberg]]] #''Tom Swift and His Triphibian Atomicar'' 1962 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Megascope Space Prober'' 1962 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and the Asteroid Pirates'' 1963 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Repelatron Skyway'' 1963 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Aquatomic Tracker'' 1964 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His 3-D Telejector'' 1964 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Polar-Ray Dynasphere'' 1965 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Sonic Boom Trap'' 1965 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and His Subocean Geotron'' 1966 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and the Mystery Comet'' 1966 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and the Captive Planetoid'' 1967 (by James Duncan Lawrence) #''Tom Swift and his G-Force Inverter'' 1968 (by Thomas Mulvey) #''Tom Swift and his Dyna-4 Capsule'' 1969 (by [[Richard McKenna]]) #''Tom Swift and his Cosmotron Express'' 1970 (by Richard McKenna) #''Tom Swift and the Galaxy Ghosts'' 1971 (by Vincent Buranelli)
A few of the Tom Swift Jr. books are in the [[public domain]] and available as downloadable texts from [[Project Gutenberg]].
==Books of the third series== #''The City in the Stars'' 1981 (by [[William Rotsler|Bill Rotsler]] & Sharmon Divono)<ref name="rotsler">{{Cite web | url = http://www.locusmag.com/1997/News/News11.html#rotsler | title = News archive | last = | first = | date = November 1997 | website = | publisher = [[Locus (magazine)|Locus]] | accessdate = 2008-06-10}}</ref> #''Terror on the Moons of Jupiter'' (by Bill Rotsler & Sharmon Divono) Introduction of Aristotle the Robot<ref name="rotsler"/> #''The Alien Probe'' (by Bill Rotsler & Sharmon Divono)<ref name="rotsler"/> #''The War in Outer Space'' (by Bill Rotsler & Sharmon Divono)<ref name="rotsler"/> #''The Astral Fortress'' (by Bill Rotsler & Sharmon Divono)<ref name="rotsler"/> #''The Rescue Mission'' (by Bill Rotsler & Sharmon Divono)<ref name="rotsler"/> #''Ark Two'' 1983 (by Neal Barrett, Jr. probably) #''Crater of Mystery'' 1983 #''Gateway to Doom'' (by Bob Vardeman){{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} #''The Invisible Force'' 1984 (by [[Neal Barrett, Jr.]]) #''Planet of Nightmares'' 1984 #''Chaos on Earth'' (Never released, manuscript available at the New York Library) (by Neal Barrett, Jr.) #''The Micro World'' (Never released, manuscript available at the New York Library) (by Neal Barrett, Jr.) Eleven titles were released in paperback by Wanderer Books, an imprint of [[Simon & Schuster]]. The first 9 were also printed for libraries in hardcover with dust jackets. Neal Barrett, Jr. and Mike MacQuay also wrote some of the books.{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} A twelfth (''Chaos on Earth'') and thirteenth (''The Micro World'') book were written, but never published.
==Books of the fourth series== # ''The Black Dragon'' (April 1991, by [[Bill McCay]]) # ''The Negative Zone'' (April 1991, by Bill McCay) # ''Cyborg Kickboxer'' (June 1991, by [[Steven Grant]]) # ''The DNA Disaster'' (August 1991, by F. Gwynplaine MacIntrye) # ''Monster Machine'' (October 1991, by [[Debra Doyle]] & [[James D. Macdonald]]) # ''Aquatech Warriors'' (December 1991, by Debra Doyle & James D. Macdonald) # ''Moonstalker'' (February 1992) # ''The Microbots'' (April 1992, by [[Robert E. Vardeman]]) # ''Fire Biker'' (June 1992) # ''Mind Games'' (October 1992, by [[Bruce Holland Rogers]]) # ''Mutant Beach'' (December 1992, by Robert Vardeman) # ''Death Quake'' (February 1993, probable author Bridget McKenna) # ''Quantum Force'' (April 1993)
===Hardy Boys and Tom Swift Ultra Thrillers by Franklin W. Dixon=== #''Time Bomb'' (August 1992) #''The Alien Factor'' (June 1993)
==Books of the ''Tom Swift: Young Inventor'' series== #''Into The Abyss'' (June 2006) #''The Robot Olympics'' (June 2006) #''The Space Hotel'' (October 2006) #''Rocket Racers'' (January 2007) #''On Top Of The World'' (May 2007) #''Under the Radar'' (October 2007) #''Extraterrestrial Highway'' (February 2008, unpublished)
There are ISBN's registered for volumes 8-11 in this series, but the titles are unknown and it is unknown if any manuscripts exist.

{{Infobox artefact | image = [[File:Minoan Bull-leaper.jpg|220px]] |name = Bronze Group of a Bull and Acrobat |image_caption = |material = Bronze |size = L: {{convert|15.5|cm|in}}
H: {{convert|11.4|cm|in}}
W: {{convert|4.7|cm|in}} |writing = |created = 1600BC-1450BC |period = Late Minoan I |place = [[Rethymnon]], [[Crete]] |location = G12/1, [[British Museum]], London |id = |registration = {{British-Museum-db|1966,0328.1|id=399328}} }} The '''Minoan bull leaper''' is a bronze group of a bull and leaper in the [[British Museum]]. It is the only known largely complete three-dimensional sculpture depicting [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]] [[bull-leaping]].{{cite web |title=A History of the World - Object: A bronze statue of an acrobat leaping over a bull from the island of Crete. |date=22 September 2008 |accessdate=6 June 2010 |publisher=BBC and British Museum |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/ahistoryoftheworld/objects/eU0DV7kOQ5inxmklD__YIw}} Although bull leaping certainly took place in Crete at this time, the leap depicted is practically impossible and it has therefore been speculated that the sculpture may be an exaggerated depiction.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/asset-viewer/minoan-bull-leaper/JgEavxWd-gLX9w|title=Minoan bull leaper|publisher=British Museum|accessdate=5 June 2010}} This speculation has been backed up by the testaments of modern-day bull leapers from [[France]] and [[Spain]].{{Cite episode |title=A history of the world in 100 objects|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/iplayer/console/b00qg5mf |series=1 |network=BBC |station=Radio 4 |airdate=February 10, 2010|number= 18}} ==Description== [[File:Minoan Bull-leaper 2.jpg|thumb|right|The Minoan bull leaper from the front.]] The group was cast in a single mould using the [[lost-wax casting]] technique. The group's homogeneity was demonstrated by analysing the composition of the bronze of bull and leaper: both contain about 96% [[copper]] and 1.5% [[tin]], with 1% [[zinc]].{{harvnb|Craddock|1976|pp=93–113}} The low proportion of tin in the alloy would have made it difficult for the bronze to fill the mould, resulting in the missing lower legs of the leaper, and probably the arms. Stylistically, the group is coherent, since the arched back of the leaper mirrors the flying gallop posture of the bull. ==Background== [[Arthur Evans]], the excavator of [[Knossos]], first published this object in the ''[[Journal of Hellenic Studies]]''.{{harvnb|Evans|1921|pp=247–259}} Evans dated the bull-leaper to the Late Minoan I period, so that this object dates to approximately 1600 BC.{{cite web | title = Collections Database Online | publisher = [[British Museum]] | url = https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/search_object_details.aspx?objectid=399328&partid=1&searchText=minoan+bull+leaper&fromADBC=ad&toADBC=ad&numpages=10&orig=%2fresearch%2fsearch_the_collection_database.aspx¤tPage=1 | accessdate = 4 June 2010}} It was acquired by the British Museum in 1966 as part of the collection of Captain Edward George Spencer-Churchill (1876-1964). He acquired it in Crete in 1921. {{Cite journal | last = Higgins | first = R. | authorlink = Reynold Higgins | title = Recent Acquisitions by the British Museum | journal = Archaeological Reports | volume = 13 | issue = 13| pages = 47–52 | year = 1967 | doi=10.2307/580975| jstor = 580975 }} The object was widely known before its acquisition and display in the Museum. It was illustrated in several general books{{harvnb |Hall|1928|p=172, fig. 221&222}}{{harvnb|Hutchinson|1962|p=265, pl.16}}{{harvnb|Lamb|1929|p=27, pl.6}} and exhibited at the British Academy in 1936.{{harvnb|Myres|1936|pp=9, 17}} ==Bull-leaping== Bull leaping and bulls in general are believed to have been an important part of Minoan culture; excavations at Knossos have revealed several [[fresco]]s depicting bull-leaping.{{cite web|url=http://ancienthistory.about.com/od/bronzeage/ss/091008Minoan.htm|title=Knossos - Minoan Art work|accessdate=5 June 2010}} It has been suggested bulls may have had some religious significance to them for example the large, exaggerated size of the bull compared to the human leaper may give an idea of the Minoans' reverence for the power of the animals. This object has been central to discussions of bull-leaping, since Arthur Evans used it as the basis for his reconstruction of the mechanics of the leap: the leaper grabs the bull's horns, executes a back flip onto the bull's back and then dismounts. As John Younger has pointed out, although this reconstruction has become part of bull-leaping in the popular imagination, comparatively few Minoan depictions show exactly this schema. The majority show the leaper diving over the bull's horns onto the back.{{harvnb |Younger|1976|}} ===Size of ancient Minoan bull leaping bulls === Archaeological evidence has now uncovered that the type of bull used by ancient Minoan bull leapers was a cross breed giant aurochs bull, now extinct in Europe. It had a shoulder height of over 6 ft (180 cm) and a hoof size similar to the size of a human head.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ev-WeyQjCWk{{verify source|date=July 2014}} ==Media appearances== The bull-leaper was object 18{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/content/features/a-history-of-the-world-in-100-objects |title=A History of the World in 100 Objects |publisher=Radio Times |date= |accessdate=2010-06-06}} in the BBC Radio 4 Series [[A History of the World in 100 Objects]]. Week 4 of the series was 'The Beginning of Science and Literature': [[Neil MacGregor]] emphasised the importance of bronze, used to manufacture tools as well as art objects, and its central role in Mediterranean trade in the Bronze Age. The BBC promoted ''A History of the World in 100 Objects'' with television adverts. One of these was a 30-second commercial featuring a Spanish [[:es:Recortador (tauromaquia)|recortador]] (bull-leaper) created by the ad agency [[Fallon Worldwide]].{{cite web |title = History of the World |publisher = [[Fallon Worldwide|Fallon]] |url = http://www.fallon.co.uk/historyoftheworld |accessdate = 6 June 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100608081055/http://www.fallon.co.uk/historyoftheworld |archivedate = 8 June 2010 |df = }} ==See also== * [[Bull-Leaping Fresco]] ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== * {{Citation | last = Craddock | first = Paul | authorlink = | title = The Composition of the Copper Alloys used by the Greek, Etruscan and Roman Civilizations. 1. {{For|works from the Western world|Night in paintings (Western art)}} [[File:Hiroshige, The moon over a waterfall.jpg|thumb|220px|Hiroshige, ''The moon over a waterfall'']] The depiction of '''night in paintings''' is common in [[Eastern art]]. [[Painting]]s that feature the night scene as the [[theme (arts)|theme]] are mostly [[portrait]]s and [[landscape]]s. Some artworks which involve [[religious]] or [[fantasy]] topics use the quality of dim night light to create mysterious atmospheres. They tend to illustrate the illuminating effect of the light reflection on the subjects under either [[moonlight]] or [[artificial light]] sources. {{TOC left|limit=4}} {{-}} ==Historical overview== [[File:Yoshiwara bij nacht-Rijksmuseum AK-MAK-1571.jpeg|thumb|[[Utagawa Kunisada II]], ''Yoshiwara by night'']] Early oriental artists created works that focused on design and spiritual interpretation of their subjects rather than realistic, three-dimensional representations. For centuries, eastern night paintings were spiritually and emotionally evocative works with unshaded, two-dimensional imagery. Like the western world, the moon, candles, and stars helped set the nocturnal scene. But there were also items, such as clothing and tree leaves, that might be used in a specific way to express nighttime from an eastern perspective. The 16th century [[Mughal painting|Mughal painter]] [[Basawan]] was an early artist who integrated western techniques and perspective into eastern art.[http://www.metmuseum.org/Collections/search-the-collections/60050334 ''The Origin of Music: Page from a Tutinama Manuscript.''] New York: Metropolitan Museum. Retrieved 29 August 2012. When trade opened up between the far east and the west art slowly changed in both sides of the world. For instance, Japanese [[ukiyo-e]] prints influenced Parisian artists. And, Jesuit priests, like [[Matteo Ricci]], brought artwork to China that introduced western approaches for [[perspective (visual)|perspective]] and [[shading]].[[Edmund Capon|Capon, Edmund]] and Mae Anna Pang (1981). ''Chinese Paintings of the Ming and Qing Dynasties''. Catalogue. International Cultural Corporation of Australia. p. 120. These factors broadened the way in which nighttime was portrayed everywhere. ==Symbolism== Black and grey shades often symbolize [[gloom]], [[fear]], mystery, [[superstitions]], [[evil]], [[death]], [[secret]], [[sorrow (emotion)|sorrow]]. The light source in most religious paintings symbolize [[hope]], guidance or [[divinity]]. In fantasy paintings light could symbolize magic. ==By country== ===Cambodia=== File:Wat mural.jpg|''Wat Mural'', 1903-1904, Phnom Penh's Silver Pagoda File:Reamkermural1.JPG|''Reamker mural'', Cambodia File:Khmer Painting at Wat Phnom.JPG|''Khmer painting,'' Wat Phnom Cambodian paintings often took the form of [[mural]]s,{{#tag:ref|Much historical Cambodian art, such as the collections of the Founan-Chenla, Angkor, Lungvek, and Oudong periods, was destroyed during the reign of the Khumer Rouge, starting 1975 and the preceding years of American bombings from 1964-1975.Ang, SamSam. (March 2, 2010). [http://www.culturalsurvival.org/publications/cultural-survival-quarterly/cambodia/preserving-cultural-tradition-ten-years-after-khme ''Preserving a Cultural Tradition: Ten Years After the Khmer Rouge.''] Cultural Survival. Retrieved 30 August 2012.Wubin, Zhuang. [http://www.aaa.org.hk/Diaaalogue/Details/1144 ''Mekong Spring: Cambodian Photography in the Last Decade''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130609063926/http://www.aaa.org.hk/Diaaalogue/Details/1144 |date=2013-06-09 }} Asia Art Archive. Retrieved 30 August 2012.|group=nb}} and have religious significance. Before 1200, art in the temples mostly portrayed scenes from the Hindu pantheon; after 1200, Buddhist scenes began to appear as standard motifs.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} Its art was heavily influenced by the artistry of India.Le May, Reginald. (1962). ''A Concise History of Buddhist Art in Siam.'' Tuttle Publishing. (2nd edition). p. 1. {{ISBN|0-804-80120-7}}. ===China=== Traditional Chinese artists sought to capture the interrelated, vast and multifaceted aspects of nature here are on earth and in the heavens. From the article "The Great Art of China's 'Soundless Poems'", Heaven appears "before us only this bright shining mass; but in its immeasurable extent, the sun, the moon, stars and constellations are suspended in it, and all things are embraced under it."[http://www.schillerinstitute.org/fid_97-01/99sp_leni_rubenstein_chinese_art.pdf ''The Great Art of China's 'Soundless Poems'.''] The Schiller Institute. Retrieved 28 August 2012.{{rp|52–53}} Night scenes, not otherwise distinguishable from daytime in Chinese art, include candles, light emanating from a building, the moon, or lake mists.{{rp|70}} Symbolism plays an enduring role in the telling of a story through painting or other Chinese art. For instance, stars and the moon are important both for religious significance and as an illustration of [[Chinese mythology]].Welch, Patricia Bjaaland. (2008). ''Chinese Art: A Guide to Motifs and Visual Imagery.'' Art and Design Series. Tuttle Publishing. p. 10. {{ISBN|0-804-83864-X}}. Symbols used in art may be grouped into four overarching categories: religious imagery, divine and mortal beings, symbols from nature and inanimate objects.Welch, Patricia Bjaaland. (2008). ''Chinese Art: A Guide to Motifs and Visual Imagery.'' Art and Design Series. Tuttle Publishing. p. 12. {{ISBN|0-804-83864-X}}. Some examples of symbols include bats which means both good wishes and good luck. The moon, aside from religious and mythical connotations, can also mean a month. The particular way an image is depicted has meaning - like a round eyed-cat means it's a night scene.Welch, Patricia Bjaaland. (2008). ''Chinese Art: A Guide to Motifs and Visual Imagery.'' Art and Design Series. Tuttle Publishing. p. 13. {{ISBN|0-804-83864-X}}. Artists use rice paper, silk or wood panels to paint night scenes. Silk has illuminating effect, while wood panels create a dark background. ====Battle==== File:Battle of Oroi-Jalatu.jpg|A collaboration between Chinese and European painters, ''The Battle of Oroi-Jalatu'', (China, [[Qing Dynasty]]), 1756 ====Folklore and literature==== =====Literature===== File:Zhou Wenjing-Visiting Dai Kui on a Snowy Night.jpg|[[Zhou Wenjing]], ''Visiting Dai Kui on a Snowy Night'', 15th century (China, Early [[Ming Dynasty]]), [[National Palace Museum]] File:Liu Jun-Visiting Pu on a Snowy Night.jpg|[[Liu Jun (painter)|Liu Jun]], ''Visiting Pu on a Snowy Night'', 15th century (China, Early Ming Dynasty), [[Palace Museum]]. File:Leng Mei - Figures - Spring Evening Banquet.jpg|[[Leng Mei]],''Spring Evening Banquet'', (China, [[Qing Dynasty]]), 1677-1742, National Palace Museum, Taipei. File:Gai Qi Hong Lou Meng 2.jpg|Gai Qi, ''Scene from 'Dream of the Red Chamber','' c. 1816, Qing Dynasty ''Dream of the Red Chamber'' and ''Strange Stories from a Chinese Studio'' were inspiration for night time paintings. Almost 500 legendary tales written by [[Pu Songling]] are compiled in ''[[Strange Stories from a Chinese Studio]]'' or ''Liaozhai Zhiyi''. The tales, inspired by oral storytelling, include strong mythical characters like ghosts, immortals, beasts and foxes. They also offer commentary about people, particularly the privileged and court officials, whose human frailties may result in unfair, unjust and other unfavorable treatment to others.[http://history.cultural-china.com /en/221H12432H14964.html ''Themes of Strange Stories from a Chinese Studio.'' Cultural China. Retrieved 1 September 2012.] He wrote with vivid imagery about the music of heaven, the inability of the light produced by a fire-fly to illuminate the demons of the night, red rings in the sky that shear the heads off of men, and the six conditions of existence: men, sinners, angels, demons, beasts and devils. Nighttime is a symbol for people's inability to understand the world around them. And the supernatural beings are meant to be a mirror to examine the nature of man. From a preface by T'ang Meng Lai to the book, Lai states that the book should prompt the readers to reflect upon the following: "We marvel at devils and foxes: we do not marvel at man. But who is it that causes a man to move and to speak?"Sung-ling, Pu (author) and Herbert A. Giles (translator). (1880). [https://archive.org/stream/strangestoriesfr00pusuuoft#page/n7/mode/2up ''Strange Stories from a Chinese Studio.''] London: Thomas De La Rue and Company. pp. xviii-xxvi. One collection of the illustrated stories is at the National Museum of China.[http://114.255.205.171/english/tabid/549/Default.aspx?AntiqueLanguageID=3805 Illustrated collection of ''Strange Stories from a Chinese Studio'']. National Museum of China. Retrieved 1 September 2012. =====Ghosts and hell===== File:Dai Jin. The Night Excursion of Zhong Kui. 189,7x120,2. Palace Museum, Beijing.jpg|[[Dai Jin]], ''The Night Excursion of Zhong Kui'', 15th century, [[Palace Museum]], Beijing. File:Yanluo.JPG|''Yanluo'', judge of Hell, inspired by the Hindouist deity Yama Many of the Chinese ghost beliefs have been accepted by neighboring cultures, notably Japan and south-east Asia. Ghost beliefs are closely associated with the traditional Chinese religion based on ancestor worship, many of which were incorporated in [[Taoism]]. Later beliefs were influenced by [[Buddhism]], and in turn influenced and created uniquely Chinese Buddhist beliefs. [[Zhong Kui]] is a [[Chinese mythology|mythological]] figure, generally a vanquisher of ghosts and evil beings, and reputedly able to command 80,000 [[demon]]s. Another mythological figure is ''Yan luo'', the judge of Hell. ====Mood setting==== File:Han Gan Night-Shining White.jpg|[[Han Gan]], ''Night-Shining White Horse,'' ca. 750, [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] File:Ma Yuan-Banquet by Lantern Light.jpg|[[Ma Yuan (painter)|Ma Yuan]], ''Banquet by Lantern Light'', circa 1200 (China, [[Song Dynasty]]), [[National Palace Museum]], Taibei. File:Ma Lin Guests.jpg|[[Ma Lin (painter)|Ma Lin]], ''Waiting for Guests by Lamplight'', circa 1250 (China, Song Dynasty) File:Dai Jin-Traveling in Spring Returning at Night.jpg|[[Dai Jin]], ''Returning Late from a Spring Outing'', 15th century, (China, Early [[Ming Dynasty]]), [[National Palace Museum]]{{#tag:ref|Likely made in the 15th century. [[Dai Jin]] was born in 1388, which would have made him twelve at the turn of the century.|group=nb}} File:Landscape after Night Rain Shower.jpg|[[Kun Can]], ''Landscape after Night Rain Shower'', (China, Qing Dynasty), 1660, [[Palace Museum]], Beijing. File:YuanJiang-Penglai Island.jpg|[[Yuan Jiang]], ''Penglai Island'', 1708, [[Palace Museum]] File:A Night Banquet at Peach and Plum Garden in Spring.jpg|[[Huang Shen]], ''A Night Banquet at Peach and Plum Garden in Spring'', (China, [[Qing Dynasty]]), before 1772 Chinese artists focus on the spiritual qualities of the painting and on the ability of the artist to reveal the inner harmony of man and nature, as perceived according to [[Taoism|Taoist]] and [[Buddhist art|Buddhist]] concepts.[[Robert van Gulik]], "Gibbon in China. An essay in Chinese Animal Lore". The Hague, 1967. Artists, like [[Su Shi]] used their skills in [[calligraphy]] (the art of beautiful writing) to make ink paintings that expressed ideas based upon the philosophies of Chinese dynasties and Confucius. Their works also express their feelings and the inner spirit of their subject.{{rp|42, 45–46, 48, 50}} Within a night scene, homesickness is expressed by flying birds looking to find a place to rest for the night{{rp|65}} =====Han Gan, ''Night-Shining White Horse''===== Han Gan created ''Night-Shining White Horse'' to dramatically capture the spirit of the imperial stallion, a symbol of China's powerfulness using only ink and paper. The stark image, without color or shading, exposes the true essence of the scene.Hearn, Maxwell. (June 2008). [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/chin/hd_chin.htm ''Chinese Painting.''] In Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History. New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 29 August 2012. =====Ma Lin, ''Waiting for Guests by Lamplight''===== ''Waiting for Guests by Lamplight'' was painted in the Song Dynasty by [[Ma Lin (painter)|Ma Lin]],Barnhart, R. M. et al. (1997). ''Three thousand years of Chinese painting''. New Haven, Yale University Press. p. 133. {{ISBN|0-300-07013-6}}[http://painting.npm.gov.tw/npm_public/System/View.jsp?type=1&ObjectID=347 ''Ma Lin - Quietly Listening to Wind in the Pines''.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222190906/http://painting.npm.gov.tw/npm_public/System/View.jsp?type=1&ObjectID=347 |date=2014-02-22 }} National Palace Museum. (Chinese) Retrieved 5 August 2012. son of famous Chinese painter [[Ma Yuan (painter)|Ma Yuan]].{{#tag:ref|Ma Lin was from a famous family of painters, out of which, for at least 150 years, one painter in each generation received official appointment to the Imperial Painting Academy.|group=nb}} Using ''shi i'' ([[English language|English]]: poetic ideas){{#tag:ref|''Shi i'', poetry inspired painting, is similar in outcome to the [[three perfections]] practice. |group=nb}}, Ma Lin painted the evening scene based upon a poem by Su Shi. In it, a man sits in the door of a pavilion during a full moon. A gentle mood is set by soft, low-lying fog before the mountains and crabapple trees. Leading up to the building is a line of candles specially placed near the blossoming crab apple trees - to "illuminate their beauty".{{rp|45}} The poem by 11th century poet [[Su Shi]] that inspired Ma Lin is:
My fear is that in the depth of night, The flowers will fall asleep and depart. So I light the tall candles, To illuminate their beauty.{{rp|45}}
====Moon==== File:OngSchanTchowPineInMoonlight.jpg|Ong Schan Tchow, ''Pine In Moonlight'' (China) In Chinese night paintings, the moon often symbolizes loneliness of the painting's character. It also sets the mood for a romantic setting. Chinese paintings also depict [[Chinese mythology|mythological]] characters who symbolize moonlight activity, such as [[Yue-Laou]], the "old man of the moonlight" and [[Chang'e]], the Chinese goddess of the moon.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} =====Chang'e, goddess of the moon===== ''The Goddess Chang'e in the Lunar Palace'' depicts [[Chang'e]], the Chinese goddess of the moon from [[Chinese mythology]].{{#tag:ref|From Chinese legends, Chang'e was the wife of a hunter named Yi. She drank a potion intended for her husband that made her immortal. She then flew to the moon, afraid that her husband would be angry with her, where she lives in a moon palace.[http://www.asia.si.edu/collections/singleObject.cfm?ObjectNumber=F1909.244a ''The Goddess Chang'e in the Lunar Palace.''] Freer - Sackler, The Smithsonian Institution's Museum of Asian Art. Retrieved 28 August 2012.|group=nb}} The late Ming dynasty fan painting shows her outside the Palace of Boundless Cold. ''Chang'e Flying to the Moon'' is a contemporary depiction of the goddess. ====Political statement==== {{wide image|Gu Hongzhong's Night Revels 1 edit.jpg|2000px|[[Gu Hongzhong]], ''Night Revels of Han Xizai'', (China, [[Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms]]), 10th century |dir=rtl}} ''Night Revels of Han Xizai'' was painted by [[Gu Hongzhong]] during the [[Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms]] period when dynasties replaced one another at an alarming rate. Fives vignettes are told about a party that Han Xizai, a minister of Li Yu, hosts. In the first scene (viewed from right to left), Han listens to the [[pipa]] with his guests. Then, he watches dancers, takes a rest, plays string instruments, and finally sees guests off. It is believed that this painting was made in response to a request by emperor Li Yu to Gu,[http://depts.washington.edu/chinaciv/painting/tliterat.htm ''The Private Realm of the Literati.''] University of Washington: A Visual Sourcebook of Chinese Civilization. Retrieved 27 August 2012.[http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en_artqa/2003-09/24/content_39759.htm ''Han Xizai at Night Dinner Painting Depicts Extravagant Life.''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061211034819/http://www.chinaculture.org/gb/en_artqa/2003-09/24/content_39759.htm |date=2006-12-11 }} China Culture, Ministry of Culture, China. Retrieved 27 August 2012. following Han's declination of an offer to be Prime Minister. One interpretation is that the painting was a way of chastising Han for having a carefree nightlife rather than accepting greater political responsibility.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} ===India=== [[File:Indischer Maler um 1650 (I) 001.jpg|thumb|200px|Artist unknown, ''Radha at night'', circa 1650 ([[Mughal painting|Mughal]]), [[Kupferstichkabinett Berlin|Kupferstichkabinett]] Berlin]] For traditional art, there is little difference between the way night and day are illustrated and the colors that are used. For instance in early [[Rajput painting|Rajput (also called Rajasthani) paintings]], the only way to read that the painting is a night scene is through the presence of torches or candles. Later in the Rajput period, both somewhat influenced by Western art, night scenes were painted dramatically with shadows and [[Mughal paintings]] used [[chiaroscuro]] for shading.Coomaraswamy, Ananda K. (2003). ''History of Indian and Indonesian Art''. Kessinger Publishing. pp. 128, 131. {{ISBN|0-766-15801-2}}. Although there are a number of schools that taught painting during India's history, there is great similarity among them to evoke charming, romantic scenes. The scenes may include moonlight or lanterns to set an amorous mood.Sharma, Lokesh Chandra. (2008) [1980]. ''A Brief History of Indian Painting''. Krishna Prakashan Media. pp. 71, 74, 75, 80, 122. Such was the case for 19th century artist, Chokha, who enjoyed making night paintings like ''Escapade at Night: A Nobleman Climbs a Rope to Visit his Lover.'' In that painting Chokha captures the tension of lover climbing several stories into a house with many people and a sleeping guard. Chokha also liked to capture twilight hunting scenes. He astutely conveyed the effects of lighting variation between twilight and the darkest night.[http://www.metmuseum.org/Collections/search-the-collections/60047179#fullscreen ''Escapade at Night: A Nobleman Climbs a Rope to Visit his Lover''.] New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 29 August 2012. ''Rao Bhoj Singh Stalking a Tiger at Night'' is a painting attributed to the Hada Master of the Kota school. In this case the dark is used for dramatic impact. It provides a dark backdrop to the bright figures of the treed hunting party, riled tiger and battered cow that was used as a lure.[http://www.metmuseum.org/Collections/search-the-collections/60050335 ''Rao Bhoj Singh Stalking a Tiger at Night.''] New York: Metropolitan Museum. Retrieved 29 August 2012. ====Romantic scenes==== File:Love Scene Central India (Malwa).jpg|Artist Unknown, ''Love Scene Central India'', 1660-1680, [[Brooklyn Museum]][http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/111971/Love_Scenes/set/e27a64a829815ff18f65b4f26f10d09a ''Love Scene.''] Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved 29 August 2012. File:Brooklyn Museum - Lovers on a Moonlit Night.jpg|Artist Unknown, ''Lovers on a Moonlit Night'', circa 1775 (India), [[Brooklyn Museum]][http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/106640/Lovers_on_a_Moonlit_Night/set/d5fc3be4d74c6e3cedec8bb1e160c606 ''Lovers on a Moonlit Night.''] Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved 29 August 2012. File:Bazrupmati.jpg|(Murshidabad) style, ''Baz Bahadur and Rupmati'', c. 1760, India Office Library ''Baz Bahadur and Rupmati'' (not showsn) depicts mistress Rupmati and Muslim ruler Baz Bahadur. The scene is illuminated from the moon on the horizon.[http://www.bl.uk/catalogues/indiaofficeselectpd/FullDisplay.aspx?RecordId=015-000004234 ''Baz Bahadur and Rupmati riding in a moonlit landscape near Mandu.''] India Office Select Materials, British Library. Retrieved 28 August 2012.[http://imagesonline.bl.uk/imagemap/?search=Natural+World&level=1&cat_id=10&last_cat_id=&page=20 ''Baz Bahadur and Rupmati''.] Images Online. India Office Select Materials, British Library. Retrieved 28 August 2012. ===Japan=== While paintings are generally a snapshot of a moment in time, the Japanese iji dôzu ([[English language|English]]: "different time, same illustration") technique is used to is illustrate activities that occur in different periods of time. ''A Long Tale for an Autumn Night'' uses that technique through a progression of time and activities over one night.{{#tag:ref|This is similar in concept to [[Paolo Uccello]]'s triple-painting set of the [[Battle of San Romano]] that begins in dawn and ends tragically in the dead of night.|group=nb}} During the Autumn night a Buddhist monk and his lover experience a fearful night of a demon in initially disguised as a man, a battle, and threat of suicide - all the more sinister by the gloom of night.[http://www.metmuseum.org/collections/search-the-collections/60038545 ''A Long Tale for an Autumn Night''. Scroll 3.] New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 29 August 2012. Note: there are three web pages, one for each scroll. [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/2002.459.1 Scroll 1] and [http://www.metmuseum.org/collections/search-the-collections/60038544?img=0 Scroll 2] ====Battle==== File:Illustrated Story of Night Attack on Yoshitsune's Residence At Horikawa, 16th Century.jpg|Artist unknown, ''Illustrated Story of Night Attack on Yoshitsune's Residence At Horikawa'', 16th century (Japan) File:Kunichika Toyohara - Sen Taiheiki gigokuden - Walters 95339.jpg|[[Toyohara Kunichika]], ''Sen Taiheiki gigokuden'', 1890, [[Walters Art Museum]] ====Folklore and literature==== =====Ghosts and witches===== File:Yoshitoshi The Ghost.jpg|Tsukioka Yoshitoshi, ''The Ghost of Genji's Love'' based upon the book ''[[The Tale of Genji]], 1886 File:Yoshitoshi, Oya Taro Mitsukuni.jpg|Tsukioka Yoshitoshi, ''Ōya Tarō Mitsukuni'' from the series One Hundred (Ghost) Stories from China and Japan (Wakan hyaku monogatari), 1865. =====Demons and hell===== File:Hyakki Yako 1.jpg|[[Hyakki Yagyō]], ''Night Parade With One Hundred Demons scroll'', Edo period, Japan, Metropolitan Museum of Art[http://www.metmuseum.org/Collections/search-the-collections/60050081 ''Night Parade of One Hundred Demons.''] New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 29 August 2012. File:Avici hell.jpg|Artist unknown, ''Avici hell,'' 13th century (Japanese), Tokyo National Museum =====''One Hundred Aspects of the Moon''===== In the 19th century [[Tsukioka Yoshitoshi]] made a series of 100 [[ukiyo-e]], Japanese wood block prints, called ''One Hundred Aspects of the Moon'' that introduced Japanese and Chinese folklore during a period of increasing western presence. The works captured "a moment in time and held suspended by a poetic dialogue with the moon." The moon symbolized different meanings depending upon whether it was a full moon or not. The moon's "waxing and waning", also used as the basis of the Japanese lunar calendar, could illustrate what time of the month an event occurred and an ascribe a manner in was to be interpreted, such as the character's loneliness.[http://www.internationalfolkart.org/exhibitions/past/moonweb/about.html ''One Hundred Aspects of the Moon'' ]{{#tag:ref|Yoshitoshi's death poem was: "Holding back the night, With its increasing brilliance, The summer moon.|group=nb}} File:YoshiOldwoman.jpg|Tsukioka Yoshitoshi, ''Gravemarker Moon'', 100 Aspects of the Moon #25, 3rd month of 1886 File:Yoshitoshi - Wang Changling - Tsuki hyakushi no. 54.jpg|Tsukioka Yoshitoshi, ''Wang Changling'', 100 Aspects of the Moon #54, 1887 File:Pleine lune Mushasi Yoshitoshi.jpg|Tsukioka Yoshitoshi, ''Full Moon in Mushasi'', 100 Aspects of the Moon, 1890 In ''Gravemarker Moon'', the famous poet [[Ono no Komachi]] meditates on the arrogance and heartlessness she displayed to her suitors as a young beauty.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} ''Wang Changling'' is the name of the poet who wrote: "The night is still and a hundred flowers are fragrant in the western palace. She orders the screen to be rolled up, regretting the passing of spring with the Yunhe across her lap. She gazes at the moon, the colors of the trees are hazy in the indistinct moonlight."{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} =====''Tale of Genji''===== File:Ch20_asago.jpg|Tosa Mitsuoki,{{#tag:ref|The illustration about Asagao (chapter 20) is traditionally credited to Tosa Mitsuoki (1617–1691)|group=nb}} ''Illustration of the Tale of Genji'', late 17th century File:Brooklyn Museum - Scene from the Tale of Genji - overall.jpg|''Scene from the Tale of Genji'', 16th century, Brooklyn Museum ''Tale of Genji'' also included [[Night in paintings (Eastern art)#Ghosts and witches|''Tale of Genji's love'']], which has an illustration. ====Landscapes==== File:Snowclad houses in the night.jpg|[[Yosa Buson]], ''Snowclad houses in the night'', 1778 (Japan), Miho Museum of Art File:Toyokuni II - 8 Famous Views (Meisho Hakkei), Night Rain at Oyama (Maya Mountain).jpg|Utagawa Toyokuni II, ''Night Rain,'' Maya Mountain from the 8 Famous Views of the Xiao and Xiang Rivers, late 18th century - early 19th century File:Hiroshige nuit de neige à Kambara.JPG|Utagawa Hiroshige, ''Nuit de neige à Kambara '' File:100 views edo 098.jpg|Utagawa Hiroshige, ''Fireworks at Ryōgoku (Ryōgoku Hanabi), [[One Hundred Famous Views of Edo]] #98'', 1858, Brooklyn museum File:Hiroshige Travellers on a mountain path at night.jpg|Utagawa Hiroshige, ''Travellers on a mountain path at night'' According to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, ''Night Rains'', of the 8 Famous Views of the Xiao and Xiang Rivers, is "a venerable theme in both Chinese and Japanese painting".[http://www.metmuseum.org/Collections/search-the-collections/60001247 ''Night Rain at the Double-Shelf Stand''.] New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 29 August 2012. ''Fireworks at Ryōgoku'' captures the popular summer entertainment called "taking in the cool of the evening."[http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/121712/Fireworks_at_Ryogoku_Ryogoku_Hanabi_No._98_from_One_Hundred_Famous_Views_of_Edo/ ''Fireworks at Ryogoku (Ryogoku Hanabi), No. 98 from One Hundred Famous Views of Edo''.] Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved 29 August 2012. ====Mood setting==== File:Watanabe Shotei14.jpg|Seitei (Shotei) Watanabe, ''Blue Birds at Night'', 1851-1918 File:Utagawa Yoshitaki - Night Traveler - Walters 9590.jpg|[[Utagawa Yoshitaki]], ''Night Traveler'', circa between 1860 and 69 (late Edo), [[Walters Art Museum]] File:Matsuke Heikichi - Nogaku zue - Walters 95249.jpg|[[Kōgyo Tsukioka]], ''Nogaku zue'', 1899 (Meiji), [[Walters Art Museum]] File:Omoda Seiju 1.jpg|Omoda Seiju, ''Yotsuyu (Night Dew)'', 1926 (Japan) ====Moon==== File:New Moon over the brushwood gate.jpg|''New Moon over the brushwood gate'', 1405 (Japan), [[National Treasure of Japan]] File:Nishimura Shigenaga - Four Seasons – Autumn Moon above the Reception Room.jpg|Nishimura Shigenaga, ''Four Seasons – Autumn Moon above the Reception Room,'' 1725–1730 File:Brooklyn Museum - Two Girls on the Veranda Looking at the Moon - Suzuki Harunobu.jpg|Suzuki Harunobu, ''Two Girls on the Veranda Looking at the Moon,'' 18th century, Brooklyn Museum. Hiroshige Man on horseback crossing a bridge.jpg|[[Utagawa Hiroshige]], ''Man on horseback crossing a bridge, [[The Sixty-nine Stations of the Kiso Kaidō]]'' Suzuki Harunobu made many night paintings, including ''Two Girls on the Veranda Looking at the Moon.''[http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/search/?q=Two+Girls+on+the+Veranda+Looking+at+the+Moon&prev_q=&x=33&y=11 ''Two Girls on the Veranda Looking at the Moon.''] Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved 29 August 2012. Many of the settings were warm relational studies, such as ''Night Rain at the Double-Shelf Stand'' which includes a parlor scene with two young women and a boy. A soft mood is set with the presence of a tea set and portable hearth for boiling water. The Metropolitan Museum of Art states that this painting is a nod to ''Night Rains'' of 8 Views of the Xiao and Xiang Rivers, a painting well respected by both the Japanese and Chinese. ===Korea=== File:Water-Moon Avalokiteshvara.jpg|''Water-Moon Avalokiteshvara'', first half of the 14th century, [[Goryeo dynasty]], Korea, Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York File:Landscapes in the Style of An Kyeon-Evening.Bell.from.Mist.jpg|''Landscapes in the Style of An Kyôn: Evening Bell from Mist-Shrouded Temple and Autumn Moon over Lake Dongting,'' 15th century, Chosôn dynasty, Metropolitan Museum of Art File:Hyewon-Jeongbyeon.yahwa.jpg|[[Shin Yunbok]], ''Chatting at a well at night'', In the late [[Joseon]] period, presumed after 1805, [[Gansong Art Museum]] in [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]] File:First Electric Light at Gyeongbok Palace 1887.png|Geumchoo Nam-ho Lee, ''First Electric Light at [[Gyeongbok Palace]]'', 1887 ([[Korean art|Korean]]), Korea Electric Power Corporation File:Brooklyn Museum - Rabbits and Moon.jpg|Artist Unknown(Korean), ''Rabbits and Moon'', 19th century, Brooklyn Museum Buddhism was an important part of Korean art since about the time of the [[Unified Silla]] period when there was a desire to be open to other religions. This resulted in the use of Buddhist themes in art work and the creation of Buddhist temples. In the 14th century, a work was made of ''Water-Moon Avalokiteshvara'',Smith, Judith G. (1998) ''Arts of Korea.'' Metropolitan Museum of Art. pp. 29, 33. {{ISBN|0870998501}}. a compassionate and wise bodhisattva who wears a halo as a sign of his divinity and has waves of water splashing his feet. A legendary hare stands under a cassia tree in the moon creating the elixir of immortality.[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/14.76.6 ''Water-Moon Avalokiteshvara.''] Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 3 September 2012.Smith, Judith G. (1998) ''Arts of Korea.'' Metropolitan Museum of Art. p. 180. {{ISBN|0870998501}}. ===Laos=== File:Bodhisatta Gautama with bowl.jpg|''Bodhisattva Siddhartha Gautama with bowl'', date unknown, Laotian monastery ===Persia=== File:The poet Sa'di converses by night with a young friend in a garden. Miniature from Gulistan Sa'di. Herat, 1427. Chester Beatty Library, Dublin. f.3r.jpg|''The poet Sa'di converses by night with a young friend in a garden'' ([[Gulistan of Sa'di]] miniature), 1427 (Persia), Chester Beatty Library, Dublin. ===Thailand=== File:Wat Pho Chai mural, Bangkok, Thailand - 20101028.jpg|[[Wat Pho]] Chai mural, Bangkok, Thailand File:Hanuman1.jpg|''Hanuman'', mural painting, Wat Phra Kaeo, Bangkok ==By religion== ===Buddhism=== File:Brooklyn Museum - Amitabha Buddha Triad.jpg|''Amitabha Buddha Triad,'' ca. 16th century. [[Hanging scroll]], Brooklyn Museum[http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/120770/Amitabha_Buddha_Triad/set/1361a342107cd2ce764cd22c7e5928b2?referring-q=Amitabha+Triad ''Amitabha Buddha Triad''.] Brooklyn Museum. Retrieved 30 August 2012. File:Joseon-Brahma-Peomcheon.jpg|''Brahma with Attendants and Musicians'' (Pômch’ôn), 16th century, Joseon dynasty, Korea, Metropolitan Museum of Art File:Okabe - The cat witch.jpg|[[Utagawa Kuniyoshi]], ''Okabe'', c. 1844. File:Yoshitoshi - 100 Aspects of the Moon - 93.jpg|[[Tsukioka Yoshitoshi]], ''A Buddhist monk receives cassia seeds on a moonlit night'' or ''Bonso tsukiyo ni keishi o uku'', from ''100 Aspects of the Moon,'' before 1892 File:Buddhist-hell-Thailand-3.jpg|''Mural on a Buddhist temple'', date unknown, northern Thailand ''Brahma with Attendants and Musicians'' depicts a [[Brahma]] ([[Korean language|Korean]]: Beomcheon) heaven scene which was painted during the early Joseon dynasty in Korea. Brahma, a Hindu deity, also became part of the Buddhist religion and protected the Buddhist teaching. The heavenly scene is includes musicians with flutes, violins, lutes and other instruments.[http://www.metmuseum.org/Collections/search-the-collections/60006939 ''Brahma with Attendants and Musicians''.] Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 2 September 2012. Smith, author of ''Arts in Korea'', writes: "His abode, the Brahma heaven, was construed as a place of pleasure, populated with heroes, entertainers and musicians." The work, replete with evidence of grandeur, includes two figures who represent the moon and sun.Smith, Judith G. (1998) ''Arts of Korea.'' Metropolitan Museum of Art. p. 178. {{ISBN|0870998501}}. [[Utagawa Kuniyoshi]] made ''Okabe'' about 1844 which depicts the death of Buddha. In recounting the death of Buddha, cats are supposed to be the only animals that not to weep. In Kuniyoshi's time, it was believed that when a girl visited a temple after dark, she took the risk of being greeted by an old woman who would offer her to stay the night. Once inside the house, the old woman would become a witch and devour her. Therefore, a cat around temples could be the witch in a cat form. ===Islamic=== ====Muhammad's night ride==== File:Muhammad during the Mi'raj - from Jami al-Tawarikh.jpg|[[Rashid-al-Din Hamadani]], ''Night Ride'', c 1315 (Persian), [[Edinburgh University Library]] File:Muhammad 1514.jpg|Artist Unknown, ''The Night Journey of Muhammad on His Steed'', 1514 (Persia), Bukhara, Uzbekistan File:Miraj by Sultan Muhammad.jpg|[[Nizami Ganjavi]], ''The Ascent of Muhammad to Heaven on his steed Buraq, guided by Gabriel and escorted by angels.'', 1539-43 (Persia [[Safavid Dynasty]]), [[British Library]] File:Mohammed Splits the Moon.jpg|Artist unknown, ''Mohammed Splits the Moon'', 16th century (Persia, [[Safavid dynasty]]), Saxon State Library, Dresden, Germany. ====Other Islamic scenes==== File:Babur-drunken.jpg|[[Farrukh Beg]], ''A Drunken Babur Returns to Camp at Night after a boating party in celebration of the end of Ramadan ('id) in 1519'', 1589 (Pakistan, [[Mughal painting|Mughal]]), Lahore, Pakistan File:IbrahimIbnAdham 24563.jpg|''Ibrahim ibn Adham visited by Angels'', 18th Century (Middle East, [[Mughal painting|Mughal]] miniature), Mughal Islamic art collection ===Jainism=== File:Kevalajnana.jpg|''Kevala Jñāna of Mahavira'' The painting ''Vigil on the Sixth Night after Mahavira's Birth'' depicts four women celebrating the birth of [[Mahavira]]'s (599-527 BC) birth.[http://www.metmuseum.org/collections/search-the-collections/60049300?img=0 ''Vigil on the Sixth Night after Mahavira's Birth: Folio from a Kalpasutra Manuscript''.] Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 30 August 2012.[http://www.metmuseum.org/Collections/search-the-collections/60004780 ''Night Vigil for Mahavira's Birth: Folio from a Kalpasutra Manuscript.''] Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 30 August 2012. ==Gallery== File:Nuit pluvieuse Karasaki Hoeido Eikyudo.jpg|Hoeido et Eikyudo, ''Rainy night in Karasaki'' File:Nissaka Man receiving a child fron a ghost.jpg|[[Utagawa Kuniyoshi]], ''Nissaka'', c. 1844 File:Matsuke Heikichi - Nogaku zue - Walters 95269.jpg|[[Kōgyo Tsukioka]], ''Nogaku zue'', 1899 (Meiji), [[Walters Art Museum]] ==See also== * [[Eastern art]] * [[History of painting]] * [[Night photography]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * Bonnefoy, Yves (compiled) and Wendy Doniger (translator).
